svn/trunk@2
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
Created the project proposal for the NLP toolkit.
The following sections have been written:
  - overview
  - design criteria
  - toolkit design and implementation

The following sections have not been written:
  - documentation
  - preliminary design and implementation

svn/trunk@237
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
Did a fairly substantial reorganization of the ChartParser module
    - Added inline documentation for most methods/classes
    - Added a new StrategyClass, and made the notions of chart rule &
      strategy more formal.
    - Turned rule methods (TD_init) into functions, since this makes it
      clearer how you should define new ones.  Also, the old ones used internal
      parser variables, etc., which they probably shouldn't.
    - Redefined rule functions (TD_init, etc., to return a list of
      edges, rather than adding the edges themselves.  The ChartParser
      is now responsible for adding them
    - Defined some standard strategies
    - Wrote a new implementation for SteppingChartParser.  Most likely
      broke the old implementation.  The new impl doesn't keep making
      new charts (that made nltk.draw.chart very difficult).  The
      internal impl of the new SteppingChartParser is a bit messier,
      but I think that the interface is cleaner.  (See its usage in
      nltk.draw.chart).

Still to do:
    - clean up code more
    - add more docs
    - Figure out a better name than "explicit"
    - change edge internal rep?

svn/trunk@271
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
nltk.draw.chart.ChartView:
  - general clean-up
  - added docstrings
  - made FONTSIZE a member variable of the chart, which can be changed
    with set_font_size
  - Added comments describing all member variables of ChartView
  - Fixed bug in RuleView destroy method
  - Changed the order of the arguments to ChartView, to make root
    optional.  If no root is specified, then a new window is created,
    with a "Done" button.
  - Made the tree-view frame and the source-view frame optional.  They
    are controlled by the keyword arguments "draw_tree" and
    "draw_source" to ChartView.  Currently, draw_tree defaults to 0
    and draw_source defaults to 1.  The ChartDemo class uses
    draw_tree=1 and draw_source=1
  - Added facility for marking edges.  Edges can be marked with any
    color, using the mark_edge method.  They can be unmarked with
    unmark().  This is currently used by ChartDemo to mark the most
    recently added edge when stepping.
  - Cleaned up & concolidated edge-coloring code.  Now it's all
    handled by _color_edge.
  - Edges that span the entire chart are now colored green.  This
    makes it easier to pick them out.
  - Cleaned up edge-selection code
  - Changed CHART_LEVEL_SIZE to a member variable; now it varies with
    the font size.
  - Changed the loclines to be lighter (less visible)

nltk.draw.chart.ChartDemo:
  - Added a text field that displays the rule that generated the last
    edge.  This is useful with strategies that contain more than one
    rule, to see which rule is being applied.
  - Added zoom-in and zoom-out buttons, that change the ChartView's
    font.
  - Changed the default test grammar & string

Message:
- Moved unchunk to chunkparser.py
  - Moved chunk scoring code to chunkparser.py.  Converted scoring
    code to the ChunkScore class.  ChunkScore is a utility class for
    scoring parsers; it can be used to combine scores from multiple
    parses (e.g., multiple sentences).  It can also be queried for the
    set of missed chunks, incorrect chunks, etc.

svn/trunk@344
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Reimplementing ChunkScore to be more efficient..
  - calculate true positive, false positive, false negative counts
    as you score.
  - removes repeated set union (which was inefficient, esp. since
    set union returns a new set)
  - keep lists of true positives, false positives, and false
    negatives, but limit their size (default=100, but you can
    change the limit with keyword args to the constructor)
  - interface is (almost completely) compatible with previous impl.

svn/trunk@468
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
- Changed _Node and _Edge to split draw from construction; now you can construct them,
  and wait to draw them (e.g., until you decide where you want them)
- Added color() to _Node and _Edge; and font() to _Edge (currently used for epsilon
  transitions)
- Added erase() methods to hide nodes/edges
- Changed _Edge to go from node->node rather than between specific coordinates
- Added a preliminary _LevelNode class as a helper for arranging nodes in a level-based
  layout
- Added preliminary level-based layout algorithm
- Changed dimensions of the demo canvas


svn/trunk@469
Author: Edward Loper

svn/trunk@472
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Debugged determinization code
Added accessible() to determine node accessibility
Added prune() to delete transitions from/to inaccessible states


svn/trunk@473
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
- Added classes FSAFrame, which creates a frame with a canvas &
  scrollbars, and puts a CanvasFSA in it.
- Added class FSAWindow, which gives an easy way to create a window
  with an FSAFrame in it.
- Added constants VIEWBORDER and SCROLLBORDER to control how much
  space is put around the fsa on the canvas
- Fixed node-dragging with scrollbars; added bounds checking to
  node-dragging
- Added _curve attribute to edges, to prevent edge overlap.
- Lower edge tags, so the tag_binds of nodes take precedence (makes
  node-dragging much easier)
- Added code to CanvasEdge to handle self-looping edges
- Added a collapse_edge param to CanvasFSA: this causes it to display
  mutliple edges between the same nodes as one edge, with their labels
  separated by commas.
- Improved node-arranging code somewhat: now placing nodes into levels
  using depth-first, rather than breadth-first, algorithm.
- Added code to properly handle arrangement for cycles: we select the
  node which can reach the most unexpanded nodes as the node to add to
  level 0.
- Got rid of _LevelNode


svn/trunk@474

- FSAFrame trys dfs first; if it's too wide, it tries bfs.
- test routines updated to be compatible with changes to nltk.fsa
- Added support for centered node labels (in addition to above-node
  labels); default is currently centered.

svn/trunk@624
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
Overhaul of the chart parser, to simplify it and make it consistant with
the new parser interface..
  - Defined an interface for chart rules
  - Replaced ChartParserStrategy class with just lists of chart rules
  - Updated to work with new parser interfaces
  - Updated to work with new CFG definition
  - Made 2 implementations of the chart parser: 1 uses what were formerly
    called "static rules" and the other uses what were formerly called
    "edge triggered rules".  The static one is the simpler -- its rules
    are ChartRules and it is ChartParser.  The one with what were "edge
    triggered rules" is IncrementalChartParser, and it uses
    IncrementalChartRules.  The intuition is that each rule is defined
    in terms of which new edges to add, *given that a specific edge was
    just added*.  Note that this is *not* necessary for any rules, but
    does help efficiency a lot for some (e.g., fundamental, bottom-up,
    etc)
  - Got rid of a bunch of docstrings (they're not correct/relevant anymore)
  - Got rid of callbacks
  - Removed a bunch of accessors (they may get added back soon)
  - Completely new definition of SteppingChartParser (it's a bit cleaner
    now) based on ChartParser (not IncrementalChartParser)
  - New demo code
  - Don't rely on edge.fr, edge.self_loop_end, etc, since we're phasing
    those out.

svn/trunk@670
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
- Revamped the basic visualization system.
  - Replaced old CanvasWidgetI with a new CanvasWidget abstract class,
    that handles most of the basic functions that canvas widgets need
    (interaction, movement, etc)
  - Added several new basic canvas widgets:
    - TextWidget: displays a string of text
    - BoxWidget: places a box around a canvas widget
    - OvalWidget: places an oval around a canvas widget
    - ParenWidget: places parenthases around a canvas widget
    - BracketWidget: places brackets around a canvas widget
    - SequenceWidget: keeps widgets in a horizontal line
    - StackWidget: keeps widgets in a vertical line
    - SpaceWidget: empty space widget, for layout
    - ScrollWatcherWidget: makes sure the scrollregion includes all
      child canvas widgets
  - Added CanvasFrame, which encapsulates a canvas & scrollbars, and a
    ScrollWatcherWidget.  It also creates a main window if no parent
    is given.
  - Added a simple demo.

Message:
- Replaced Edge class with a new Edge interface, that has two
  implementations: TokenEdge and ProductionEdge.  A TokenEdge
  records that a token occurs in the text; a ProductionEdge
  records that a tree has been found to be (partially) consistant
  with the text.

svn/trunk@767
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
Complete rewrite of nltk.probability.  The new nltk.probability is
less flexible in some ways, but should work out better.  It is
signifigantly simpler, which should make it easier for students to
understand.  Also, under the old design, doing statistical estimation
would be very cumbersome.
  - no more events
  - FreqDist is now a class, not an interface
  - FreqDist.cond_max and FreqDist.cond_freq are replaced by using a new
    class, ConditionalFreqDist, to encode conditional frequency
    distributions.
  - Similarly, ConditionalProbDist replaces ProbDistI.cond_max and
    ProbDistI.cond_prob.
  - Rewrote the probability distributions
  - Added docs to probability distributions
  - Freq dists no longer have bins; the number of bins is specified
    when doing statistical estimation, if necessary
  - CrossValidationProbDist now uses HeldoutProbDist to do most of its
    work.

svn/trunk@874
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
- Changed sort order for chart edges
- Added a sort to TopDownRule, to give it the same behavior as
  Earley's algorithm (this may be removed when we actually add
  Earley's algorithm).
- Sort the edges for BottomUpRule, so we process them left-to-right
- Sort the incomplete edges for FR, to give it the same behavior as
  Earley's algorithm (this may be removed when we actually add
  Earley's algorithm).
- Changed order of rules in TD_STRATEGY
- Changed SteppingChartParser.step to continue using a rule for
  as long as it applies (to give Earley's algorithm behavior).
  This may get removed later.
- Reverse the order of the new chart edges in SteppingChartParser,
  so they match the order used in the normal ChartParser.

svn/trunk@1127
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
- Renamed "CorpusI" etc to "CorpusReaderI" etc, to make it clear that
  we're providing corpus readers, not the actual copora
- Updated docstrings, to make this corpus/corpus reader distinction clear.
- Added CorpusReaderI.path() method
- Fixed typo in CorpusReaderI.open() docstring
- Removed subcorpora(), subcorpus() from CorpusReaderI, replaced them
  with groups()
- For __repr__, only catch IOError
- Changed default behavior of CorpusReaderI.license() and
  CorpusReaderI.copyright() to return 'Unknown' instead of None.
- Removed license and copyright options from SimpleCorpusReader (but
  retained copyright_file and license_file)

- Added a new corpus reader for the treebank
  - 4 groups: raw, tagged, parsed, merged
  - If the merged group isn't available, then compute it on-the-fly
  - Expose the merge() method, in case anyone wants to use it.


svn/trunk@1128

  [ and ] bracketings).

svn/trunk@1382

svn/trunk@1383
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
- Improvements to the efficiency of the location object:
  - Define a LocationContext object, that's used to store a
    <unit,source> pair.  These are shared among locations, so each
    location only needs one pointer for unit/source, not 2 (saves
    ~1 word/location); and makes several operations faster (since
    we can check for pointer equality between LocationContext
    objects before doing a full equality check).
  - Intern unit strings.
  - added a new implementation, nltkLen1Location, which is used for
    locations with a length of 1.  These objects don't store an
    end index; only a start index.  (saves 1 word/location for the
    common case of length-1 locations).
  These improvements take the average space/location down from 6
  words/location (=24 bytes) to 4 words/location (=16 bytes).  c.f.
  to ~35-40 words (140-160 bytes) that are used by the Python
  implementation.

- Improvements to the efficiency of the type object:
  - use a single list for properties, with alternating property
    names and property values (saves 1 word/type).

- misc bug fixes

(note that the Token implementation is not yet functional)


svn/trunk@1384
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
- Improvements to the efficiency of the type object:
  - Use the VAR protocol to store a type's properties directly in
    the type object (rather than in a separate auxilliary array).
    This saves 1 word/type (down from 4+2p to 3+2p, where p is the
    number of properties defined by the type).

svn/trunk@1401
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
- Moved docstrings from ctoken.c to ctoken.h
- Changed location context implementation to use Python tuples instead
  of structs.  (This allows for better garbage collection, etc).  But
  the location-context tuples should never be visible from python.
- Changed type implementation: now each type contains a pointer to
  a property name list; and only the property values are stored inside
  the type object.  This means that types can share property name
  lists (facilitated by a cache), so the avg size overhead for types
  decreases by about 1 word per type.
- Always maintain the property name lists in sorted order (sorted by
  the ids of property names, which are interned strings).  This makes
  comparisons between properties easier.
- fixed a few minor bugs
- Added more documentation

svn/trunk@1858
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
- Christopher Maloof's implementation of the Brill tagger, with lots of
  clean-up.  This is copied from contrib/nltk_contrib/upenn/cis530/
  spring2003/christopher_maloof, with the following changes:
    - training split out into different classes (BrillTaggerTrainer,
      FastBrillTaggerTrainer)
    - merged rules.py into brill.py
    - renamed the brill rule & template classes.  (eg RuleI -> BrillRuleI)
    - Completed changes to use new token architecture (w/ property
      indirection, etc)
    - Several nomenclature changes, to make things more clear (e.g.,
      introduced the term "fixscore" to distinguish from the actual
      score, etc.)
    - Refactored & simplified templates & rules
    - Improved trace output
    - Removed explicit save/load functions (you can just pickle the
      tagger itself).
    - refactored _best_rule, to make it shorter & easier to read (added
      several helper methods)
    - lots of code & docstring clean-up

Still to do:
  - make sure behavior is identical to the original
  - add the fast trainer (not transfered yet)
  - clean up testing/demo code.

svn/trunk@1972
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
- Check that the children argument is not a string (this is to prevent
  people from accidentally saying things like Tree('x', 'y') instead
  of Tree('x', ['y']).
- Check that the first element of a tree-position index to an int.
  Otherwise, if the user says tree['foo'], they'll get an infinite
  recursion (because 'f'[0] = 'f').  This way, they'll get something
  like "'f' is not an int".

Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Fixed a couple of bugs:
* 'check_reentrances' should be 'check_reentrance'
* It seems the FeatureBindings constructor could never be run with arguments,
  because it expected them as keyword arguments (with **initial_bindings), but
  the keys of 'initial_bindings' are FeatureVariables, and the keys of keyword
  arguments have to be strings. I changed 'bindings' to a plain argument to
  make this work.

svn/trunk@2140
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Fixed bug: chunk scoring of deeply nested trees caused hashing exception.
Modified code to freeze the leaves, not just the nodes.


svn/trunk@2141
Author: Trevor Cohn

Message:
Changed reading to allow 'I-X' to follow other tags than just 'B-X', by
interpreting them as 'B' tags. This means that the output of machine learners
can be loaded, rather than just the gold standard.

Changed reader to return the top level tree from the stack, not the bottom,
which often leaves out parts of unfinished sentences. The gold standard has a
number of erroneous newlines, which caused parts of the sentences to
disappear, as they're not terminated with a full stop.

svn/trunk@2254
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Simple version of Brown Corpus reader.

This is a single function which iterates over the corpus, returning
tuples consisting of a word and a POS tag.

Here's what happened to members of the original class:

These methods were moved to the docstring, since they'll be more
useful there: name(), description(), license(), copyright()

These methods were unnecessary:

* items() -- because the structure of the corpus on disk as been
    simplified, e.g. collapsing ca01-ca44 into a single file 'a'.

* installed() -- now incorporated into a method which gets the
    full path to a corpus file

* path(), open(), raw_read() -- these raw access methods are
    redundant given that the simplified tokenization is raw

* read() -- becomes the corpus tokenizer, the only function left

* groups() -- just an argument to read; you need to see the docstring
    to know what the group names are; they are now simplified, e.g.
    "A. PRESS: REPORTAGE" is now just "a".

svn/trunk@2263
Author: Ewan Klein

Message:
A new approach to backoff tagging:

1. initialize tagger t2 passing it another tagger t1 to backoff to
2. training t2 doesn't complicate t2's model with tagging cases that
   are covered by t1, keeping t2 smaller
3. t1's context must be less specific (or a subset of) t2's context

  that image.

  passing them to publish_file

  not "Figure" or "Example"

svn/trunk@3194
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Modifications in response to Ewan's comments:
- Removed discussion of message understanding and IE (now in new nlpir chapter).
- Dropped point about chunking being application-specific.
- Clarified point about chunking being fine-grained relative to parsing
- Clarified point about chunking being linear time complexity
- Removed section 5.4, put some of the material on chinking back in 5.2.
- Deleted sentence about location information.
- Sorted out problem with call to leaves() vs flatten()
- Reworked code that had called randint to make it more accessible to readers
- Added reference back to recently added discussion in tagging chapter re baselines
- Added comment about the internal inconsistencies of chunking corpora.

svn/trunk@3274
Author: Stuart Robinson

Message:
Added yaml support, and doctests that make use of it; ensured that bound
variables are output as their values, not as variables.

I modified the yaml code slightly - mapping keys are sorted whenever possible,
and there's a new yaml.show() method that works like yaml.dump() but does not
default to "flow style" output.

svn/trunk@3307
Author: Ewan Klein

Message:
Change parse() method of Lexicon class. If its unique_entry flag is set to True, it will throw an error if two or more entries have the same key. Keys are associated with lists of entries now, instead of single entries---i.e., there can now be a one-to-many mapping between keys and entries.

svn/trunk@3309
Author: Ewan Klein

Message:
Don't import methods using fixed path, just use the local ones. We want to ensure that this module will refer to its own methods regardless of where it ends up, which is an issue because it MAY replace nltk_lite.corpora.shoebox.

svn/trunk@3310
Author: Stuart Robinson

Message:
Asymmetrical unification works along with aliases now. The last thing to deal
with is that variable bindings are, infuriatingly, not preserving reentrance.

The YAML serializer now makes anchors that look like &1 instead of &id001.

Added tags2string function that maps a list of tagged tokens to a string,

A different separator can be selected using an optional sep argument.

variables.

Message:
- Fixed selection sort such that the supplied list is correctly sorted.
 - Merge sort does NOT function as intended. I believe this is due to scoping issues - the assignment of the newly merged list is lost once each recursive call returns. This cannot be easily solved without returning the list (as opposed to reordering it in-place, as the other sort methods do).

- Leacock-Chodorow similarity measure now implemented. Note that this requires that the maximum depth of the noun and verb taxonomies be known; currently there is a helper function (not included in this module) that brute-force calculates this with a running time of 5 - 10 minutes, but obviously a more elegant solution will need to be devised at some point in time.

svn/trunk@3724
Author: Ewan Klein

Message:
- Added new methods path_distance_similarity(), leacock_chodorow_similarity() and wu_palmer_similarity() to the Sense class. All three return a number denoting the similarity of two Senses. The first two are more or less complete and give the same results as do Pedersen's Perl versions (http://www.d.umn.edu/~tpederse/similarity.html) but the third does not, because of an ambiguity in the algorithm.
- Also added one support class (OrderedSynset) and a couple of utility methods; these may be moved to the wntools.py file later.

svn/trunk@4069
Author: Ewan Klein

Message:
- Added book.txt, used to generate the entire book as a single html
  or pdf file.  A single pagination is used across the entire book,
  and crossreferences between chapters works fine.  A table of contents
  and an index are generated.
- Added support for external (cross-chapter) cross-referencing
- Added support for defined terms (`foo`:dt:) and indexed terms 
  (`foo`:idx:)
- Added index.txt, used to generate `index.html`, an index that points
  to the separate `<chapter>.html` files for each defined term or 
  indexed term.
- Tweaked heading contents for latex output
- Section numbering is now handled by a custom transform, which will
  appropriately handle appendices, prefaces, and setting latex 
  chapter counters where appropriate.
- Fixed some section headings in `semantics.txt`
- Added missing import in tree2image.py

svn/trunk@4369
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Fixed various rst bugs, from en/rst-bugs.txt.  Email to Steven describing fixes:

1. chapter numbering.  The best thing to do here is to put ".. preface::" or ".. appendix" right before the chapter title.  You should also include a number in the title, which will automatically be converted to the right numbering system.  E.g.,:

  .. preface::

  ============================
  3. The third preface section
  ============================

  In the output, 3 will be replaced with "III".

2. pylisting.  All bugs should be fixed now.  I created a custom environment for listings, "\begin{pylisting}", for the latex output.  Feel free to change the style that's used to display it.  (Code to declare the new environment is in rst.py -- search for "\\newfloat{pylisting}{thp}{lop}"

3a. table captions.  I added a new 'table' directive, which can be used to add captions to tables.  Use it thusly:

  .. table::

     =======   =======
     column1   column2
     -------   -------
     data1     data2
     =======   =======

     Caption goes here.

3b. table sizes.  I don't see any easy way to address this, without significantly rewriting the docutils table output code.  Right now, the size of tables in the output is based on the size in the input, using ascii-art type size.  So, if an image doesn't fit, add more "---"s or "==="s to make the ascii table wider.  I realize this isn't ideal, but I won't be able to do anything better by wednesday.

4. figures.  The figure reference numbers should be correct now.  The problem was that latex was using one counter for both listings & tables, but the rst.py script was assuming there were 2 separate counters.  So this was fixed when I added a new 'pylisting' float environment.  

4b. You said that sometimes the word 'Figure' is swallowed up before a figure number -- can you give an example of a place where this happens?  (there's no example of it in rst-bugs.txt).

5. Error line numbers.  I think the issue here is that the included 'definitions.txt' adds to the line numbers.. so if you subtract out `wc -l definitions.txt`, you'll get the right number.  I'll try to look at improving the behavior of this sometime, but won't be able to by wednesday.

6. External cross references.  For some reason that I don't quite understand yet, rst ends up converting '_' to '-' in a lot of ids..  I think it might have to do with the rules in html for what ID can contain.  Anyway, in the case mentioned, you get correct behavior by saying 'Listing baseline-tagger_' instead of 'Listing baseline_tagger_'.  The easiest thing might be to just always use target identifiers with '-' instead of '_'.

7. References.  You said that references appear after the footer for you.  I don't see this in the html or the pdf output -- for me, the references come before the footer in both cases.

svn/trunk@4551
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
First pass at CSV data file for NLTK corpora.

Fields:
* nltk_directory
* short_name
* long_name
* contents
* derived_from
* reader
* licenser1
* licenser2
* see_also
* contact_name
* contact_email

The short name should be the canonical term we use to refer to the
corpus within The Book. At the moment, the default short name is the
same as the directory name in the distribution -- needs more consideration.

The 'contents' field should perhaps be thought about more; a full
listing is impractical in many cases (e.g. Timit), but it maybe useful
to indicate if only specific subparts of the full corpus are distributed.

List items within fields are separated by '::'

The 'see_also' field should contain a list of URLs.

svn/trunk@4595

Message:
nltk_lite/parse/*.py
* added cfg.covers() to check that a grammar covers a sentence
  (i.e. all the words in the sentence appear in lexical productions)
* added AbstractParse._check_coverage() which raises a ValueError
  if the grammar doesn't cover the sentence
* modified get_parse and get_parse_list in the various parser classes
  to perform this check (nowhere to abstract this).
* modified pchart demo code because parser didn't cover grammar

/doc/en/definitions.txt
/nltk_lite/__init__.py
* changed version to 0.8b1

/doc/en/words.txt
* polishing
* removed commented-out material
* reworked commented-out medline example as an exercise
* added a plotting example
* deleted example of ConditionalFreqDist for wordlengths
    conditioned on word-initial letters, as it was unmotivated
    and the technical content is covered elsewhere

* moved WordNet section to end of chapter

* notes

/nltk_lite/semantics/utilities.py
* deleted import of missing grammarfile module

/nltk_lite/probability.py
* changed FreqDist and ConditionalFreqDist initializers to permit samples to be specified

Old style:
    fd = FreqDist()
    for token in text:
        fd.inc(len(token))
New style:
    fd = FreqDist(len(token) for token in text)

svn/trunk@4646
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
*****************************
  Changed nltk_lite to nltk
*****************************


This has been done in preparation for 1.0,
in which the '-Lite' part of the name will
go away.  In the meantime the distributions
will still be called NLTK-Lite, but the package
itself will be just 'nltk'.  Code, demos, tests,
tutorials, contrib are all updated.

svn/trunk@4670
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
/doc/en/rst-bugs.py
* new issue about building
* new issue with wrapping inside glossed text cells

/doc/en/featgram.txt
* added comments about making this chapter more accessible
* changed scare quotes to double quotes (single quotes don't typeset correctly)
* changed "rule" to "production" throughout, except where it means chart rules
* changed textual FS notation to use =, for consistency with NLTK format
* removed references to NLTK that treated it like a language (e.g. create a grammar in NLTK)
* miscellaneous simplification of language

svn/trunk@4804
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
importing top-level modules, so that these can be accessed either as:

from nltk.X import Y
from nltk import *; Y
from nltk import *; X.Y

e.g.

from nltk.probability import FreqDist
from nltk import *; FreqDist()
from nltk import *; probability.FreqDist()

The last of these is currently necessary in order to access the
demo code.  Demo functions are always called demo(), which means
there is a collision when names from multiple modules are imported
into the top-level namespace.

svn/trunk@4889
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
- Modified all corpus readers to accept lists of items; in which case,
  they return 'concatenations' of the given corpus items.  If the 
  underlying corpus items are strings or lists, the obvious operation
  is performed.  If they're StreamBackedCorpusViews, then a new
  ConcatenatedCorpusView object is used.  If they're xml, then a new
  xml element is created, containing all of them, with tag 'documents'.
- Got rid of _block_reader -- it was redundant w/ read_block
- StreamBackedCorpusView now requires a filename (not a stream).
- StreamBackedCorpusView now doesn't open the file until it needs to.
- StreamBackedCorpusView now doesn't calculate eofpos until it needs to.
- StreamBackedCorpusView can now be closed and re-opened.  If it is 
  closed, it will be automatically re-opened next time it is accessed.
- StreamBackedCorpusView's iterate_from method is now public
- Fixed bug w/ negative indices (indexerror wasn't getting thrown 
  in some cases where it should get thrown)
- Fixed bug w/ length calculation (last block was getting omitted from
  the length calculation)
- Changed KeyError -> IndexError for out-of-bounds indexing in
  StreamBackedCorpusView
- Added ConcatenatedCorpusView
- Added some default values for corpus read methods
- Fixed typo in brown corpus demo

svn/trunk@4900
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
- Fixed bug in concat() -- accept subtypes of known types as well
- Changed read_whitespace_block and read_wordpunct_block to read
  blocks of 20 lines at a time (rather than 1 line at a time).  
  This will cut down on space overhead by a factor of about 20x,
  and might actually increase local random-access performance,
  because of the cache.  Random access that's really random (e.g.,
  selecting words from the document in random order), will become
  a little slower.

Message:
added ycoe corpus reader -- removed some old ycoe code, including the code for chunking.  This code might be moved to contrib at some point.  While I was at it, I also fixed several bugs in the ycoe corpus code, involving regular expressions that were matching more than they were intended to.  (The result was that some words sometimes got discarded.)

Message:
split out the chunked corpus reader from treebank

svn/trunk@4939
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
renamed chunk->chunked

svn/trunk@4940
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
moved chunked corpus reader to its own module

svn/trunk@4941
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
added to docstrings

svn/trunk@4942
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
renamed chunk->chunked

svn/trunk@4943
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
/doc/en/applied-programming.txt
* major reorganisation
* more discussion
/doc/en/structured-programming.txt
* fixed problem with stack/queue discussion reported by lfdea

svn/trunk@4944
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Reordered chapters as earlier agreed:
  5->7->8->9->11->12->5

This has many benefits, including:

* language engineering in part 1 to broaden the appeal
  of the earlier part of the book and to talk more about
  evaluation and baselines at an earlier stage
* concentrate the partial and full parsing material in
  part 2, and remove the specialized feature-grammar
  material into part 3



svn/trunk@4945
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
/doc/en/footer.txt
* updated URL for creative commons license
/doc/en/nlp-python.txt
* fixed error in java code reported by Edward Ivanovic
/nltk/test/Makefile
* added directives to produce HTML and PDF from doctest sources
/doc/Makefile.doc
* bugfix


svn/trunk@4946
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Added nltk.corpus.reader

svn/trunk@4947
Author: Ewan Klein

Message:
migrated punkt from contrib, and significantly reworked it

svn/trunk@4948
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
support incremental training

svn/trunk@4949
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
- Use a simpler (& more memory efficient) structure to store the
  orthographic contexts that we've seen each word in.
- Mark PunktTokenizer as a yaml object, for serialization
- Moved punkt's word tokenizer from tokenize.regexp to tokenize.punkt
- Fixed a bug with splicing whitespace back in when constructing
  the final result.
- Added docstrings


svn/trunk@4950
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
defer importing of wave module

svn/trunk@4953
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
minor updates

svn/trunk@4954
Author: Ewan Klein

Message:
Added a parse_featcfg() function that parallels the parse_cfg() and
parse_pcfg() functions already in the cfg module. 

This makes it easier to read in feature grammars from strings, but
also involves moving over some functionality that is currently in the

svn/trunk@4987
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
Updated the nltk.tokenize package.
  - All tokenizers are now available as subclasses of TokenizeI
  - Selected tokenizers are also available as functions
  - Function names are "whitespace_tokenize()", "wordpunct_tokenize()",
    etc.  The old "tokenize.whitespace()" etc names are still available,
    but should be considered deprecated!  They will be removed before
    nltk 1.0.
  - Simplified the code in regexp tokenizer.  It now delegates to 
    utilities.convert_regexp_to_nongrouping to convert grouping parens
    to nongrouping ones.  Once this is done, it can simply use 
    re.findall() (for gaps=False) and re.split() (for gaps=True).
    I also added a flag to control whether empty tokens are discarded
    when gaps=True -- defaults to True (matching the original behavior).
  - Changed implementation of sexpr tokenizer to something more efficient.
    Tested on treebank text, it runs about twice as fast.  I also added
    options for specifying custom parenthases (e.g., for [..[..]] style
    trees) a 'strict' parameter to decide whether mismatched parens gives
    an exception, or returns a list containing partial sexprs.

svn/trunk@5108
Author: Ewan Klein

Message:
- When a corpus view slice is created that's more than 100 words long,
  return a CorpusViewSlice object rather than a list.  That way, if
  you e.g. split a corpus into a train set and a test set, you don't
  need to load the whole corpus into memory.  (The number 100 is
  controlled by the const CorpusViewSlice.MIN_SIZE.
- Corpus views now act a little more like (immutable) lists -- they
  implement count(), index(), __contains__, __add__, __mul__, and
  __cmp__.  This was mainly done for the benefit of CorpusViewSlice,
  so that if the user takes a large-ish slice they'll still be able
  to use normal 'list' methods on it.
- Corpus views are now explicitly un-hashable.
- Fixed a bug in the handling of slice indexes that are more negative
  than the size of the corpus (e.g., for a corpus with 100 words, an
  index of -170 would previously get treated as if it were 30; but it
  should get treated as if it's 0.)
- Added read_line_block
- Added some regression test cases for corpus views.

svn/trunk@5267
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
/nltk/corpus/reader/util.py
* read_sexpr_block modified so that it only reads a block when necessary
  (previously it read a block each time it entered the loop,
  i.e. one block for each sentence returned)
  
/nltk/corpus/reader/bracket_parse.py
* five readers: with sentence-level groups we can provide
  parsed, tagged, and raw-word output, and for word-level
  groups we can provide tagged and raw-word output only.
* new regexps so that tagged and raw-word readers don't parse
  the input only to discard it
* word-level readers now use sum() on the sentence-level readers,
  as suggested by Edward

  as a parameter, and instead inspects grammar.lexicon()
* parse/featurechart.py: update to the initialization of
  FeatureEarleyChartParser

Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Following Edward's suggestion, definition of _read_block has been
modified to avoid iterating over stream. The reader now retrieves 94
articles, which conforms to results of grepping for <DOCNO>.

be emitted at the end of each file in the ieer directory -- haven't
yet figured out the cause.

According to grep, two of the documents are missing headlines.

svn/trunk@5351
Author: Sumukh Ghodke

Message:
doc/en/*.txt
* misc fixes to examples for clean doctest build
* expanded discussion of tagged corpus interfaces for corpora other
  than brown, and for other languages

nltk/corpus/reader/*.py
* refactored bracket_parse treebank reader as it included functionality
  that was not specific to bracket_parse; created new class SyntaxCorpusReader
* a consequence is that the Sinica Treebank reader now supports
  the non-parse methods, e.g. tagged_sents()
* these classes now inherit SyntaxCorpusReader:
  - BracketParseCorpusReader
  - SinicaTreebankCorpusReader
  - TreebankCorpusReader (unnecessary? -- no code touched)

nltk/corpus/reader/ycoe.py
* removed redundant import of tree
* added import for RegexpTokenizer

data/corpora/ycoe/*
* stub directory with readme to explain absence of data
  and so that help(nltk.corpus) will work
* an issue with parsing a regexp in ycoe still prevents help(nltk.corpus) from working

svn/trunk@5610
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
fixed syntax error that blocks compilation

svn/trunk@5611
Author: Ewan Klein

Message:
nltk/corpus/reader/util.py
* changed items() to documents(), to avoid name conflict;
  documents() with no argument will behave identically to items
  documents(category) with a category argument will list the documents of a given category

nltk/corpus/reader/plaintext.py
* defined ListCategorizedPlaintextCorpusReader, inheriting PlaintextCorpusReader
  and ListCategorizedCorpus, to be used for Reuters corpus.
* defined documents() method in both PlaintextCorpusReader and CategorizedCorpus
  (method resolution order favours CategorizedCorpus.documents(), permitting optional
  category argument)

nltk/corpus/reader/api.py
* defined documents() as a method of CorpusReader
* define filenames to map from one or more items (docs) or categories to the corresponding filenames
  (renders _item_filenames obsolete)
* moved CategorizedCorpus class and subclasses to api.py
* moved items and root properties to CorpusReader class

nltk/corpus/reader/tagged.py, plaintext.py
* changed nomenclature to use documents instead of items
* added categories parameter to reader methods

nltk/corpus/__init__.py
* updated definition of Reuters, Brown and Movie Reviews corpus

nltk/corpus/reader/*.py
* changed nomenclature to use documents instead of items

nltk/test/corpus.doctest
* various updates

doc/en/*.txt
* updates to usage of Brown (nltk.corpus.brown.foo('a') becomes nltk.corpus.brown.foo(categories='a'))

svn/trunk@5643
Author: Dan Garrette

Message:
Minor redesign of the corpus readers.  Instead of using 'items' or
'documents' to refer to files, just use "file identifiers," i.e.,
relative paths from the root of the corpus.  This increases
transparency and avoids making any commitment about whether
something's a document or not.  When appropriate, corpora can also
chose to define and use other identifiers.  E.g., timit defines
"utterance identifiers" and treebank defines "document identifiers."

Specific changes:

  - File identifiers differ from the item identifiers, in that file
    identifiers *do* include extensions (eg .txt).  Thus, any old code
    that explicitly refers to a specific item will need to be changed.

  - Removed separate 'extension' argument for corpus readers -- just 
    include it as part of the file list. 

  - CorpusReader base class now has a constructor that sets up a
    _root variable (availabel via 'root' property) and a _files
    variable (available via 'files()' method).  files() is a method
    instead of a property, because subclasses will sometimes want
    to override it to take extra arguments (eg, 'categories.')

  - CorpusReader.filenames is replaced by CorpusReader.abspath()
    and CorpusReader.abspaths().

  - Renamed find_corpus_items to find_corpus_files

  - Updated doctests to include extensions in file identifiers, and
    to use .files() instead of .items(), and a couple other minor
    changes that reflect the changes made to corpus readers.

Other related changes:
  - Rewraped several lines that were >80 chars wide

  - Replaced the base classes for categorized corpus readers with a single
    base class that handles both regexp-based categorizations and
    mapping-file based categorizations.  As a consequence, the names of
    the subclasses also changed (e.g., LocationCategorizedPlaintextCorpusReader
    becomes just CategorizedPlaintextCorpusReader).

  - Added/expanded a few docstrings.  Note: the timit module docstring
    still doesn't totally correspond to the implementation.

svn/trunk@5694
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
A radical change:

1. Copy wxbrowse.py to wxbrowse_OLD.py

2. Split wxbrowse.py into 2 files: wxbrowse.py & browseutil.py:
    - wxbrowse.py is the GUI part
    - browseutil.py contains general routines needed in browsing

3. Make a LOT of changes in files of step 2 for step 4

4. Create new files:
    - browserver.py A "browser-server" (see below)
    - new HTML files: index.html, index_2.html, start.html
                            upper.html, upper_2.html
                            


After all this: 2 ways to browse the wordnet database:

1. python wxbrowse.py: the old way using wxPython

2. python browserver port-num:
        2.1 Launches the default browser (if not running) and creates
             a new tab trying to make connection to:
             http://localhost:port-num/
        2.2 Starts the HTTP server for port-num serving the browsing
             requests for the wordnet database
    The default port-num is 8000

The second way is still at an early stage, though functional. And,
as always when making a LOT of changes, even the old functionality,
meaning wxbrowse.py may have suffered. The second way makes it
possible to browse the database without installing wxPython.

Message: svn/trunk@5823
Author: Jason Baldridge

Message:
* moved sentence about NLTK's uniqueness to earlier paragraph where it fitted better
* deleted sentence about the fact that providing code amounted to a bias in favour
  of CS students, since: (i) the more CS-biased texts don't provide any code, just
  exercises that presume people can code, and (ii) NLTK does a lot of convenient
  housekeeping in its code (e.g. the corpus readers) which is of primary benefit to
  the linguist audience
* moved 2.5 after 2.1 since both relate to the need to have an accessible
  programming language
* changed title of Shoebox section to mention files (we're not interfacing to
  the Shoebox software directly, only via a common file format)
* moved 4.3 into section 5, as a more natural place to talk about assignments
  (sec 4 is on classroom interaction, while 5 was on projects but now expanded
  to be on assignments and projects)
* changed texttt inline code to use a \code macro that makes it smaller



svn/trunk@5824
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
* rewrote introduction to try to highlight the issues with the students native language
  (linguistics vs computer science)
* wrote opening to section on getting started, to explain the importance of this
  given the diverse student audience, and students voting with their feet
* added discussion of student expectations
* notes on first assignment, aiming to show how one assignment could address
  the distinct learning needs of the two different audiences
* added citation of ACM paper that talks about Python's suitability for an audience
  with widely varying programming skills

  assignments which fits best in section 5

* fixed example re WhitespaceTokenizer which seemed to be expecting the constructor
  to do the tokenizing.
* added sentence to section 3 opening to serve as overview of section
* suggested another area of content for the first lecture (shared history of CS and ling)

svn/trunk@5843
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
Updates in response to feedback from workshop reviewers:

* made use of extra 9th page for many more references
* responded to reviewer 1 comment concerning how
  NLTK-based courses fit with the bent of a department
  by adding a new section 3.3 Entry Points which
  describes various pathways into the content that
  are supported by NLTK and which cites another
  workshop paper
* responded to reviewer 1 comment concerning the
  need for CS person and linguist to work in
  complementary roles by adding a comment in 3.2
  about the need to get away from typecast roles
  (this is the status quo that is already well supported
  by current approaches to teaching)
* responded to reviewer 2 comment about interfaces to
  existing packages by adding examples of Weka and Prover9
  to sec 5.2
* responded to reviewer 3 comment about how to grade difficulty
  (programming vs conceptual) by pointing out that it is
  based on the concepts covered in the preceding sections of
  the book
* added references to all our past NLTK papers and to other
  CL teaching papers that talk about NLTK that I'm aware of,
  as supporting evidence for the comment in sec 1 about
  the evolution of NLTK in response to feedback.
* other misc fixes
* added authors, affiliations and emails
* replaced many URL footnotes with full citations

Message:
fixed citation, adding extra author

svn/trunk@5845
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
- Improvements to nltk's maxent classifier & weka classifier
  - refactored feature encoding to allow for features that depend
    on the output in a nontrivial way
  - added support for using MEGAM to train maxent classifiers
  - added support for using scipy maxent trainers, if scipy is
    installed (CG, etc.)
  - added apply_features util function (and LazyMappedList class), which
    makes it easy to train classifiers on large data sets without
    using huge amounts of memory -- in particular, we don't need to
    store the full list of featureset objects in memory at once.

svn/trunk@5968
Author: Petro Verkhogliad

Message:
Rewrite of Punkt contributed by Joel Nothman <jnothman@student.usyd.edu.au>

BUG FIXES AND FUNCTIONALITY CHANGES:

- introduced _sentbreak_count to fix incremental training (was broken
  by len(sentbreak_toks), line 859)

- stop _find_rare_abbrev_types() printing to stdout without verbose
  flag

- make regular expressions more consistent, and Unicode-compliant

- problem in correct counting of frequencies for collocations due to
  not stripping period off type

- correct rules for _find_abbrev_types (rather than the four
  somewhat-redundant rules listed, just check for alpha and that type
  is not "##number##")

- the issue of what should be considered a potential collocation is
  already noted in the code; the Kiss and Strunk paper is not explicit
  enough in this regard. Nonetheless, from the work I am currently
  performing, it is clear that the collocation heuristic can capture
  cases where the log-likelihood is not high enough to have actually
  classified that word as an abbreviation. For instance, in a corpus
  where there is little consistency with regards to following common
  abbreviations (e.g. St) with a period, a collocation may still be
  identified in "St. James". I have thus added an optional flag called
  INCLUDE_ALL_COLLOCS that includes all period-final words as part of
  potential collocations. But too much noise (ordinary ends and
  beginnings of sentences) gets through if only log-likelihood is
  used, so I have also created a variable MIN_COLLOC_FREQ that will
  require the collocation to appear a minimum number of times before
  its inclusion. Nonetheless, collocations like "reasons. First" slip
  through easily, as it seems "first" is not a "frequent sentence
  starter", while "firstly" is.

- also exclude collocations with punctuation as the second token.


EFFICIENCY:

- made token annotations operate as single-pass generators operating
  on one or two tokens at a time rather than multiple passes over the
  entire set of tokens. (NB: This involved not using stand-off
  annotation in the tokenizing phase, and -- for the sake of code
  reuse -- in training as well. Although stand-off may be more
  efficient in the latter case due to multiple passes over the data,
  training is best performed incrementally in either case, and the
  size of the training text should be optimised instead. If necessary,
  I can include some functions to do that.)

- rather than tokenizing the whole text and then checking for sentence
  boundaries, only process localities where sentence boundaries may
  occur.

- separate the finding of collocations and sentence starters from
  training text processing, such that heuristics do not need to be
  recalculated for each text. Instead only perform this when
  finalize_training() is called (or if train(.., finalize=True)).

- rather than finding all abbreviations from frequencies at each
  iteration, only find ones that might have changed due to the current
  training text (i.e. _find_abbrev_types => _reclassify_abbrev_types).

- allow memory overhead to be reduced through freq_threshold(), a
  method which removes likely-insignificant data relating to
  infrequent tokens. It can be called occasionally during incremental
  training.

- make _get_orthography_data use a map ((pos_in_sent, case) => flag)
  rather than a series of repetitive if statements


CODE STRUCTURE:

- separate out regular expressions

- training and sentence boundary detection can be performed on an
  iterator of tokens (for training, must be finite in current
  implementation) instead of on a piece of text (although the
  locality-based efficiency improvement described above makes
  processing a text currently more efficient).

- add methods sentences_from_text() and sentences_from_tokens() which
  are generators, rather than returning a list as tokenize() does.

- separate PunktSentenceTokenizer into four classes: _PunktBaseClass
  is a parent of PunktTrainer and PunktSentenceTokenizer, which both
  utilise PunktParameters. The latter contains precisely the data used
  for sentence boundary detection (abbreviations, collocations,
  sentence starters, orthographic context data), and hence is an easy
  way of saving and recovering these details from training to
  tokenizing stages. The Trainer is better built for incremental
  training and more clearly encapsulates the break between collecting
  parameter data and the actual sentence boundary detection.

I have generallly retained a backwards-compatible interface in
PunktSentenceTokenizer for *non-incremental* training, unless
"customization variables" (such as ABBREV, INCLUDE_ABBREV_COLLOCS,
etc.) are modified by programs that incorporate punkt, as these are
part of PunktTrainer now. Incremental training will not work if used
in the old manner.



svn/trunk@5969
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Corrections to brown_ic.py by Jordan Boyd-Graber <jbg@cs.princeton.edu>,
to fix the following problems:

1. Doesn't do Laplace smoothing for unobserved terms (only does it for
observed terms, which is really bizarre)
2. Can get stuck in an infinite loop if a cycle exists in the WordNet
data
3. Assumes a sense/synset distinction that no longer exists in the
NLTK WordNet package
4. Assumed (incorrectly) the case of POS tags in the Brown corpus
5. Is wasteful of memory (dictionaries are keyed by synset objects
rather than by offsets)
6. The time to propagate counts is based on the total size of WN, not
the number of synset counts observed. So even if the corpus is very
small, it takes forever to compute.

svn/trunk@6028
Author: Paul Bone

Message:
Add a WordSense class to wordnet.synset which allows for (a) accessing synsets from sense keys; (b) accessing sense counts from cntlist.rev.

E.g.:
>>> from nltk.wordnet import *
>>> w = getWord('eat', 'v')
>>> w.senseCounts()
[61, 13, 4, None, None, None]
>>> w[2].words
['feed', 'eat']
>>> s = w[2].wordSense('eat')
>>> s
eat (verb) 3
>>> s.count()
4
>>> k = s.senseKey
>>> k
'eat%2:34:02::'
>>> WordSense(k).synset()
{verb: feed, eat}

Message:
Added bio_sents() and bio_words() methods to ConllChunkCorpusReader in conll.py
to allow reading (word, tag, chunk_typ) tuples off of CoNLL-2000 corpus. Also 
modified ConllChunkCorpusView to support these changes.

Added _update_cache() to HiddenMarkovModelTagger in hmm.py to support
decoding with unknown words. _update_cache() resizes the output probability
matrix, calculates new output probabilities, and adds to the symbol-to-int
mapping only. Previous probabilities are retained.

Implemented HMM-based Treebank POS tagger and phrase chunker for 
nltk_contrib.coref in api.py. Pickled versions of these objects are checked
in in data/taggers and data/chunkers.

Bug-fix to freiburg.py for elements with attributes but no attribute values.

svn/trunk@6089
Author: Meng Xinfan

Message:
- Added CustomFeatureValue, which can be used to define classes for
  base feature values that define custom unification methods.  (This
  hook is necessary for some of Petro's work on porting FUF to nltk;
  and it might be useful in other cases too.)  Note that this new hook
  allows an alternative approach to the existing hook supplied by the
  Feature class: the Feature class allows you to define 'magic
  features,' while the CustomFeatureValue class allows you to define
  'magic feature values.'
- Defer binding variables until the end of unification.  This is 
  necessary when variables are used together with CustomFeatureValue
  (or with custom Feature objects).

Open question: Should `Feature` be renamed to `CustomFeature`?  Or
perhaps even to `MagicFeature` (in which case, `CustomFeatureValue`
would be renamed to `MagicFeatureValue` as well)?  Or something else?


svn/trunk@6090
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
- Added 'jar' target to top-level Makefile and to the javasrc/
  Makefile, which builds 'nltk.jar' and places it in the 
  nltk/nltk/ directory.  Building this target requires that
  Mallet be installed; if it is not installed, then a message
  is displayed indicating how to download it, and how to tell
  the Makefile where it is located.
- Added 'nltk.jar' to the repository.  This file can also be
  built from the Makefile, but doing so requires the correct
  dependencies; so I'm also including it in the repository.
- Added nltk.internals.NLTK_JAR, which is the full path to the
  nltk.jar file.  (Note that this file may not exist.)
- In nltk.internals.java(), accept the string 'pipe' and treat
  it as subprocess.PIPE (this is just for convenience)
- Modified setup.py and MANIFEST.in to include nltk.jar file.

svn/trunk@6127
Author: Joseph Frazee

Message:
Merging changes from /branches/first_order_predicate_calc/.

The semantics code based on logic.py has been rewritten to use first order predicate logic.

sem.logic.py
- total rewrite to use first order predicate logic
- library made more extensible so that other logics can use much of the same code

inference: inference.py, mace.py, prover9.py, tableau.py
- updated for new logic.py

contrib.drt: DRT.py, resolve_anaphora.py
- updated for new logic.py
- anaphora resolution procedure extracted to a separate file to allow users to swap in different files to experiment with other resolution techniques
- cleaned up GUI code and fixed so it will work on UNIX

contrib.gluesemantics: glue.py, drt_glue.py, linearlogic.py, lfg.py, drt_glue_demo.py
- updated for new logic.py
- rewrote linearlogic.py.  it now extends logic.py
- drt_glue.py changed to reuse large portions of glue.py
- major code cleanup
- improved functionality of drt_glue_demo

contrib.rte.bow.py
- wrapped call to demo() in "if __name__ == '__main__':"

contrib.rte.logicentail.py
- updated for new logic.py
- updated for drt_glue.py changes

contrib.dependency.malt.py
- code cleanup

contrib.tag.tnt.py
- code cleanup

svn/trunk@6147
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
logic.py
 - Removed global function unique_variable() in favor of a method on Expression
 - Added is_indvar() global function to verify that a string is the appropriate form for an individual variable
 - Modified the parser so that higher-order expressions are not allowed.  This is accomplished by requiring that variables bound by quantifiers be individual variables and preventing predicates from being individual variables.  So now, 'exists P.P(x)' and 'y(x)' will both throw errors.

util.py
 - replaced reference to logic.Error with logic.ParseException

mace.py
 - updated so that predicates are not given individual variable names

svn/trunk@6157
Author: Petro Verkhogliad

Message:
logic.py
 - Modifed parser:
	'exists x.P(x) & Q(x)' is parsed as '(exists x.P(x)) & Q(x)' instead of 'exists x.(P(x) & Q(x))'
	'\x.P(x) & Q(x)' is parsed as '(\x.P(x)) & Q(x)' instead of '\x.(P(x) & Q(x))'
	'P(x)(y)' is parsed as '(P(x))(y)' instead of erroring

drt.py
 - Added DrtIndividualVariable
 - Modifed equality operator for DRS and ConcatenationDRS to handle alphabetic variance

svn/trunk@6194
Author: Ewan Klein

Message:
Refactored lazy classes (corpus readers, lazy maps, etc):

- Renamed nltk.corpus.util.AbstractCorpusView to
  nltk.utilities.AbstractLazySequence.
- Renamed nltk.corpus.util.CorpusViewSlice to
  nltk.utilities.LazySubsequence.
- Added LazyConcatenation (similar to ConcatenatedCorpusView -- perhaps
  these should be merged?).
- Added _current_toknum and _current_blocknum instance variables to
  StreamBackedCorpusView.  These can be used by the read_block()
  method in the (rare) circumstances when it needs to know where 
  the current block is in the sequence of blocks or tokens.
- Added LazyMap, which is basically a generalization of LazyMappedList
  to take more than one list.  N.b., though that the function argument
  now comes first (to match the 'map' primitive), not second (as it
  did in LazyMappedList).
- Marked LazyMappedList as deprecated -- use LazyMap instead.


svn/trunk@6195
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
- Added new ConllCorpusReader, which provides a superset of the 
  functionality provided by ConllChunkCorpusReader.  E.g., it can
  read parse trees and semantic role labelings in the formats used
  in CoNLL 2004 and 2005.  ConllChunkCorpusReader is now a subclass
  of ConllCorpusReader.


svn/trunk@6196
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
- Added PropbankPointer as a base class for the three propbank pointer
  classes.
- Fixed a bug in the PropbankTreePointer __cmp__ implementation when
  compared with objects that are not PropbankTreePointers.
- Changed the block size for the propbank corpus reader from 20 lines
  to 100 lines.


svn/trunk@6197
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
- Fixed a bug in LazySubsequence.iterate_from(start) which caused it to 
  yield too many elements when start>0.
- In LazyConcatenation, iterate through the list-of-lists rather than
  checking its length and indexing.  This is useful, e.g., if the
  underlying list-of-lists comes from a corpus view, in which case
  calculating the length of the list-of-lists would require scanning
  the entire corpus.

svn/trunk@6210
Author: Ewan Klein

Message:
- Added ProbDistI.generate() method.  The default implementation just
  walks through the sample list until the cumulative probability of
  the samples it's looked at exceeds a random number between 0 and 1.
  Subclasses are free to define more efficient implementations where
  possible (but this hasn't been done yet).
- Added SUM_TO_ONE class variable to ProbDistI, to indicate whether a 
  probability distribution's probability estimates for its samples 
  should always sum to one.  (Some don't because they 'discard' some
  probability mass to be used for unspecified unseen samples.)
- Added missing samples() method to a couple prob dist classes
- Added generation test to the demo code

svn/trunk@6267
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
- fixed bug where trees would sometimes fail when sliced
- changed tree repr to print the class of the tree (eg ImmutableTree) 
  instead of just Tree
- changed immutable trees to precompute their hash value.  This saves some
  time, and ensures that we fail early if the user tries to make an
  immutable tree with mutable node value or children

svn/trunk@6268
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
Fixed a bug that could cause infinite recursion when comparing a tree
to a non-tree

svn/trunk@6269
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
- Fixed a bug in bracketed tree parsing where ((A a) (B b)) would get
  parsed as (A a).  This happened because the code to get rid of 
  redundant empty top bracketings was buggy.

- Added Tree.parse class method.  This is basically intended to
  replace nltk.tree.bracket_parse.  I have not deprecated
  bracket_parse (yet), but bracket_parse now simply delegates to
  Tree.parse.  Advantages of Tree.parse over bracket_parse:

    - makes it easy to parse into subclasses of Tree.  E.g.,
      ImmutableTree.parse(...) works as expected.
    - gives much friendlier error messages when there is a parse error
      (see tree.doctest for examples).
    - accepts a 'brackets' argument which can be used to specify which
      character should be treated as open & close brackets
    - accepts parse_node and parse_leaf functions, which can be used
      to transform nodes & leaves (e.g., to generate feature structures)
    - accepts node_pattern and leaf_pattern, to specify (using regexps)
      what nodes & leaves should look like -- this makes it possible to
      have nodes & leaves with internal whitespace (e.g., for feature
      structure valued nodes & leaves).
    - no longer removes the empty top bracketing by default.  This can
      be enabled using the optional remove_empty_top_bracketing argument,
      but it defaults to false.  For compatibility, the bracket_parse
      function sets this to true.

svn/trunk@6378
Author: Dan Garrette

Message:
Merged zipdata branch changes r6304:6324 into the trunk.  This branch adds 
support for reading corpora and other data files from within zipfiles.
- nltk.data.find() can now handle .zip files as part of a resource
  name -- e.g., nltk.find('corpora/treebank.zip/combined/wsj_0001.mrg')
- nltk.data.find() can now handle .zip files as entries for 
  nltk.path
- nltk.data.find() now returns PathPointers rather than path 
  strings.  PathPointers can point to either filesystem objects
  (with the subclass FileSystemPathPointer) or to files within
  zipfiles (using ZipFilePathPointer).
- StreamBackedCorpusReader now accepts PathPointer values for its
  constructor's filename argument
- Modified all corpora to take PathPointer values for 'root'.

svn/trunk@6406
Author: Meng Xinfan

Message:
Updated semantics of variables() and free().

variables() now returns a set of all the variables that are available to be replaced.  This includes free (non-bound) variables as well as predicates.

free() now takes an optional argument, 'indvar_only', that tells the method to return only individual variables.  This argument is True by default.  The method has also been modified to prevent the inclusion of predicates.

svn/trunk@6470
Author: Joseph Frazee

Message:
Major reworking of the automated theorem proving modules.

- Implemented the command pattern for Theorem Provers and Model Builders.
  - Separated the proving/model building functionality from the storage of goal and assumptions.
  - The theorem proving/model building functionality is executed by the Prover or ModelBuilder class.
  - The ProverCommand or ModelBuilderCommand class stores the Prover or ModelBuilder, the goal, the assumptions, and the result.
  - Code was added to the prove()/build_model() methods of the Command classes to check whether a result exists before re-executing the tool.  This will prevent unnecessary work by the tool.
    - add_assumptions() and retract_assumptions() clear the result, forcing the user to re-call prove()/build_model() before the result will be available.
  
- Implemented the decorator pattern for Theorem Provers for use by nonmonotonic.py
  - The nonmonotonic provers are designed as decorators for the ProverCommand class.
  - The decorators store an instance of ProverCommand, and contain logic to augment the assumptions list.
  - When prove() is called on the decorator, the augmented assumptions list is passed into the underlying ProverCommand's Prover.
  - Decorators can be layered, allowing the user to mix-and-match nonmonotonic techniques.

svn/trunk@6558
Author: Dan Garrette

Message:
Reorganise ch02 to a new structure that opens with linguistically
and technically motivated content rather than just language syntax,
then progresses through an alternating series of sections on Python
and linguistic tasks.  The old material on lemmatization and stemming
has been moved from the end to the start, since this connects with
the word-counting theme of ch01 and may permit some nice exercises
on indexing (e.g. to do more sophisticated concordancing when we
only require word stems to match).  Several independent chunks of
text on files and strings have been aggregated into a single section,
but this still needs to be reworked internally.  Readers encounter
regular expressions first in the context of cleaning XML, then see
some simple tokenization, before a thorough treatment of regular
expressions once they've had this motivation.  A section on string
formatting comes last (mapping from lists to strings), complementing
the tokenization section (mapping from strings to lists).

svn/trunk@6586
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Changed the way we do program listings.  Docbook doesn't let us define
custom floating figure environments, so they have been treated as inline
examples.  However, they need to be treated as floats, so they have to
be figures.  This means they have to be numbered along with figures,
and referred to from the text as Figure N.N instead of Listing N.N.
A further consequence is that: "Listing N.N shows" -> "The program in
Figure N.N shows", so all the source chapters that contain pylistings
have had to be tweaked.

svn/trunk@6620
Author: Ewan Klein

Message:
- Reorganized VariableExpression types
  - Abstract parent class is now called AbstractVariableExpression
  - Three concrete classes: FunctionVariableExpression (ie, "P"), IndividualVariableExpression (ie, "x"), and ConstantExpression, (ie, "walk")
  - A function VariableExpression() exists as a factory that creates the correct subtype of AbstractVariableExpression based on the name of the variable passed in.  This is the preferred way to construct any AbstractVariableExpression object.
  
- Moved methods from typedlogic.py to logic.py.
  - A parameter "type_check" is available for the LogicParser() that will ensure that all Expression objects are type checked during construction.

svn/trunk@6640
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Chapters 1-3: Created content of new chapter 2 out of old chapters 1 and 2 (now 3):

2.1 NLTK Corpora (was 1.5)
2.2 More Python: Functions (was 1.4.3)
2.3 Semantic Networks (was 1.7)
2.4 More Python: Getting Organized (was 1.6)
2.5 Accessing Text on the Web (was 2.1)
2.6 Strings and Files (was 2.2)

Moved discussion of not using keywords for variable names to chapter 1, since
earlier discussion was postponed along with all the other material on strings.

Chapter 4: opening example of text.similar() included punctuation
in the output.  Modified nltk/text.py to exclude punctation tokens
from ngrams, and updated examples in chapter 4.

Misc polishing, added a couple of exercises.


svn/trunk@6641
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
ch02.rst

  the new ConditionalFreqDist.plot() method to achieve the
  same graphical display as before; thanks to its compactness
  its now feasible for readers to experiment with this kind
  of plotting interactively.

ch05-draft.rst:

  since it was rather long and a bit too generic for its current
  position at the start of chapter 5.

  multiline cumulative plots easier to produce (cf the
  cumulative word-length distribution graph in chapter 1)
* ConditionalFreqDist.conditions() now sorts its conditions
  so they are listed in a deterministic order

  and put shared computation in FreqDist._cumulative_frequencies().
  Made this function more efficient (now linear, was n^2).

svn/trunk@6709
Author: Edward Loper

Message:
- Allow short-circuiting when checking whether an expression is satisfied.
  E.g., for A&B, return false immediately if we find that A is false.
  This can make the evaluation of deeply nested epxressions like
  (exists x.(P(x) & exists y.(Q(y) & exists z.(R(y) ...)))) much faster.

Message:
Fixed bug in lowest_common_hypernyms() which caused it to give the incorrect result in many cases.  E.g. lowest_common_hypernym of whale and dog was animal (depth 6), even though they share a lower hypernym placental (depth 10).


svn/trunk@6953
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Reverted to previous implementation of root_hypernyms(), cf comment by Steven Bethard:

The reason for the original implementation was that the hierarchy has some funny
things going on. For example, in WordNet, "restrain" and "inhibit" are mutually
recursive:

# S: (v) restrain, keep, keep back, hold back (keep under control; keep in check)
"suppress a smile"; "Keep your temper"; "keep your cool"
    * direct hypernym / inherited hypernym / sister term
          o S: (v) inhibit, bottle up, suppress (control and refrain from showing; of
emotions, desires, impulses, or behavior)
                + direct hypernym / inherited hypernym / sister term
                      # S: (v) restrain, keep, keep back, hold back (keep under
control; keep in check) "suppress a smile"; "Keep your temper"; "keep your cool"

Message:
Restructured nltk.draw.wordnet_browser:

 + This no longer keeps a list of previously served pages
 + This no longer uses the contents of a page as a source of
   information to resolve the next query.
 + The contents of a page can now be modified in one part of this
   program without affecting the behaviour of another.
 + URLs now contain all the information necessary to resolve a query.
 + A number of methods have been marked as deprecated.
 + The start page is now generated dynamically rather than statically
   so that as changes are made it does not need to be manually updated
   to conform to those changes.

works (returning the exception rather than raising it).

svn/trunk@7265
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Extensive modifications and optimizations of grammars and chart parsers

nltk/grammar.py
* the lexicon isn't necessary anymore, so it was removed
* parsing CFGs, PCFGs and FCFGs is simplified
  - there's the generic functions parse_production and parse_grammar

nltk/parse/chart.py
* changes to class ChartParser():
  - new parameter use_agenda (default=True), which uses agenda-based parsing
    (a big optimization)
  - new method chart_parse(tokens) which returns the chart
* new parsing strategy: BUC_STRATEGY (Bottom-up combine)
  - prediction also move the dot forward
  - often more efficient than TD, BU and EARLEY
* simplifications to Earley
  - we don't need a lexicon anymore
  - the function makeEarleyStrategy() is unnecessary 
  - instead we have the new EARLEY_STRATEGY
  - CompleterRule is just SingleEdgeFundamentalRule

nltk/parse/featurechart.py
* all references to the lexicon are removed
  - it works fine anyway

nltk/draw/chart.py
* removed obsolete comment

nltk/parse/api.py
* corrected spelling mistake: overriden => overridden

nltk/test/parse.doctest
* replaced the ChartParser and FeatureChartParser unit tests
  with calls to the demo() functions
* added a parser test for a large grammar 

nltk/test/featgram.doctest
nltk/test/grammartestsuites.doctest
* updated the paths to the test grammars

svn/trunk@7461
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Fixed string conversion problem reported in issue 225.  Now we get a more
informative error: AssertionError: block reader _read_word_block() should consume at least 1 byte (filepos=9999)


svn/trunk@7462
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Fixed bug 209 reported by Jordan Boyd-Graber.
The default behavior of the wordlist corpus reader
was to look for a file called "en"; however this
is specific to the stopwords corpus.  In general
we cannot specify a default file.  It is reasonable
to allow users not to specify a file (and get all
files; the current behavior) in the case of corpora
like "names".


svn/trunk@7463
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Fixed syntax error and missing method reported in issue 232.
Still has a divide-by-zero error.


svn/trunk@7464
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Added Basque and Catalan treebanks (from CoNLL 2007 Shared Task, with permission).
Initial work on getting corpus readers to work with this, and with the new PTB-based
dependency treebank.


svn/trunk@7465
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
More progress on WordNet Browser.

+ Prevent a warning about a deprecated call by removing it.
+ Make relation types click-able links (they currently have no
  user-visible effect)
+ Make synset links toggle-able so that the relation types for a
  synset can be collapsed.


svn/trunk@7467
Author: Paul Bone

Message:
doc/howto/Makefile:
 * make clean no longer fails if there aren't any *.errs
   files present.

Makefile:
 * tools/mac no longer exists (as of rev 6506), make clean no longer
   tries to access it.
 * Lines starting with "Warning: " are now surpressed from the assignment of
   VERSION and NLTK_URL. Previously, on systems without i.e Tkinter, these
   variables got incorrectly instanciated and caused problems.

svn/trunk@7552
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
nltk/downloader.py
* changed hashlib.md5() to md5() since hashlib wasn't imported

nltk/tag/*.py
* batch_tag() renamed to tag_sents() by analogy with corpus readers
* tagger initializers have train_words= and train_sents= parameters
  (train_words is now the default, a gotcha for current users, so
  I've given users a detailed exception if they pass in tagged
  sentences without using the train_sents parameter
* tag.accuracy() is now a method of an individual tagger, called evaluate()
  to permit more convenient access
* removed some old deprecated code

Known issues:
* pickle file defines ClassifierBasedPOSTagger (should be ClassifierBasedTagger)
* the signature of taggers has changed (the train parameter is now split
  into train_words and train_sents) which means the pickle file is stale
* code to build pickle file should be added somewhere

svn/trunk@7645
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Pylistings are now formatted as examples in docbook, so the text surrounding any reference to a pylisting (previously e.g. "the listing in Figure 3.2") now needs to refer to it as an "Example".  All pylisting references have been updated in this way.  Also, labels for all figures and tables now have a fig- or tab- prefix.  We should now only see forms like:

Figure fig-foo_, Table tab-foo_, and Example foo_

In one place an underscore was used instead of a hyphen in a label.  Underscores need to be reserved for the _label and the xref_.

svn/trunk@7719
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Docbook xlinks are rendered as "Figure X", "Example X", "Section X", "Table X", "Chapter X" etc.  When the underlying text includes the object type, the resulting output has "Section Section X".  Therefore, all instances of these words before a citation in our source text, e.g. "Section sec-foo_", have now been deleted.

A consequence of this is that our HTML and LaTeX output would lack the extra word having the object type.  So rst.py is modified to add this in (just for HTML and LaTeX).

Note that references to linguistic examples (53) and to code callouts, do not get the extra word in any output format.  Occasionally there is prose of the form: "In example (53)", instead of "In (53)".  This is passed through, but a warning message is generated.

SIGH

svn/trunk@7807
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Completed editing of Ch01, with lots of small changes. 

Some points of note:
=============

* more handholding in the initial code examples, and more callouts
  generally.
* reworked type/token discussion
* more handholding of definition of functions; plus a terminological
  distinction between parameters (in defs) and arguments (in
  calls). Adopted "foo()" notation for referring to functions.
* added a brief example of append()
* slight expansion of text on collocations
* used "(conditional) test" in place of "conditional expression",
  since latter seems confusable with conditional statement
* re-ordered some items in summary

Unresolved issues:
============

I'm queasy about this claim:
"If we can automatically solve such problems of language understanding, we will
be able to move on to tasks that involve generating language output, such as
`question answering`:dt: and `machine translation`:dt:."

My guess is that most of the activity in MT these days uses purely
statistical techniques. Also, why have a discussion of MT in a section
entitled "Generating Language Output" immediately followed by a section
entitled "Machine Translation"? But the French example is nice, so I'm
not sure what to do.

The following doesn't format correctly (in HTML at least)  but I can't figure out why:

#. |easy| Define a variable ``my_sent`` to be a list of words, using
   the syntax ``my_sent = ["My", "sent"]`` (but with your own words,
   or a favorite saying).
   
   a) Use ``' '.join(my_sent)`` to convert this into a string.
   
   b) Use ``split()`` to split the string back into the list form
   you had to start with.

svn/trunk@7813
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Mapped `x`:gc: to ``X`` -- manual intervention for a variety of case issues,
e.g. `xp`:gc: goes to ``XP``, while `Det`:gc: goes to ``Det``.

Finished annotating ch09.  In addition to annotations I changed the following:

* converted some ..ex:: displays of feature structures into program output, which reduces the total number of examples and ensures that they correspond to the input (some didn't)

* fixed case in attribute names, e.g. there was a place where we were told that (24) is equivalent to (23), when one used uppercase attributes and the other used lowercase attributes

* reworked a few passages to use simpler language, and make slightly less use of "formalism", "framework"; in one place changed "adopt" to "illustrate" since we're not taking a stance in a theory paper; sometimes there were phrases that put the material in context, but perhaps not a context that the reader needs to know about, e.g.:

    There are a number of notations for representing reentrancy in
    matrix-style representations of feature structures.

* In the introduction to X-bar syntax, I moved the literature references and the notational remark about horizontal bars to the further reading section (though it still needs to be worked in there).
