svn/trunk@8023
Author: Joseph Frazee

Message:
Major rewrite of MUCCorpusReader somewhat based on IEERCorpusReader. It
should be much faster and much more flexible so only a few changes are
pending to make it work with MUC-7 documents.

Documents are parsed and sentences are processed only as they're needed. This helps a lot if you only need access to a subset of sentences or want to
process them incrementally, no more parsing every document and then reading
the contents.

svn/trunk@8172
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Additions to grammar.py, and a major reorganization of the chart parsers. 

The following are the main changes:

* grammar.py
 - removed the restriction on grammars that terminals can only be in  
   unary rules
 - new methods for grammars (for checking grammar format)
 - new class FeatureGrammar, for grammars with FeatStructs; the most  
   important difference with CFG is how lhs/rhs restrictions on  
   productions are implemented
 - simplified the code for reading grammars

* parse/util.py
 - new function load_parser, which craetes a parser from a grammar  
   url, where the grammar can be a CFG, FCFG or PCFG.

* parse/chart.py
 - changed names of many chart rules, deprecated others since they  
   are unneccessary
 - moved the Earley chart rules to earleychart.py
 - removed the EARLEY_STRATEGY
 - added BU_LC_STRATEGY (bottom-up left-corner)
 - added method chart_parse to ChartParser, which returns the final  
   parse Chart
 - lots of generalizations to ChartParser and Chart
 - added the classes TopDownChartParser, BottomUpChartParser,  
   BottomUpLeftCornerChartParser (convenience classes for the parser 
   strategies)
 - changes in the demo() function
 - bug fixing, code simplifications & generalizations

* parse/pchart.py
 - changed the class BottomUpChartParser to  
   BottomUpProabilisticChartParser

* parse/featurechart.py
 - deprecated load_earley: use load_parser instead
 - new class FeatureChart, with small changes to the indexes to be  
   able to use lhs/next restrictions (this together with the changes 
   in FeatureGrammar makes FCFG parsing much more efficient)
 - moved everything that has to do with Earley parsing to  
   earleychart.py
 - added FeatureChartParser, a modification of ChartParser
 - corresponding strategies TD_FEATURE_STRATEGY, 
   BU_FEATURE_STRATEGY and BU_LC_FEATURE_STRATEGY
 - corresponding convenience classes FeatureTopDownChartParser, 
   FeatureBottomUpChartParser and 
   FeatureBottomUpLeftCornerChartParser
 - some cleaning in the demo() function
 - bug fixing, code simplifications & generalizations

* parse/earleychart.py
 - new file for incremental chart parsing (of which Earley is 
   one strategy)
 - classes IncrementalChart and FeatureIncrementalChart, they divide 
   the edges into Earley "state sets", one per input position
 - the EARLEY_STRATEGY (and FEATURE_EARLEY_STRATEGY) are simply 
   top-down strategies for an IncrementalChart
 - classes EarleyChartParser and IncrementalChartParser are synonyms,  
   as are FeatureEarleyChartParser and FeatureIncrementalChartParser

* parse/__init__.py
 - changed the list of __all__ exported functions

* app/chartparser_app.py
 - removed the Earley strategy (it was too similar to top-down)
 - added a strategy Bottom-up left-corner
 - removed the "Scan/BU Init/TD Match" rule (it is removed from  
   chart.py, since it is implicit in the Chart and in the 
   Fundamental Rule)

svn/trunk@8179
Author: Peter Ljunglöf

Message:
Added LeafInitRule to all strategies. Plus fixed a bug in InstantiateVarsChart.

When instantiating an edge in an InstantiateVarsChart, we have to do 
this in-place, since the parsing algorithm might already hold a reference
to the edge for future use.

svn/trunk@8528
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Specify encodings for each file in genesis. I determined the encodings with the Unix "file" utility, which gives:

english-kjv.txt: ASCII English text
english-web.txt: ASCII English text
finnish.txt:     ISO-8859 text
french.txt:      ISO-8859 C program text
german.txt:      ISO-8859 text, with very long lines
lolcat.txt:      UTF-8 Unicode English text, with very long lines
portuguese.txt:  UTF-8 Unicode text
swedish.txt:     Non-ISO extended-ASCII text

I tried a number of different encodings with the swedish.txt file, and OEM 865 (Danish, Norwegian) seemed to produce the display most similar to http://runeberg.org/bibeln/01_01.html

svn/trunk@8531

svn/trunk@8646
Author: Dan Garrette

Message:
Created special exception hierarchy for Prover9 errors.  Fatal errors indicate serious issues such as malformed syntax.  LimitExeeded exceptions indicate that Prover9 has cut itself off because the proof was taking too long.  The distinction is useful because the undecidablity of first-order logic means that it may be useful to simply assume that long-running proofs are non-theorems.

svn/trunk@8675
Author: David Ross Coles

Message:
Add set_proxy function to nltk.util to allow easy configuration of HTTP proxy.

This function sets up the required handlers for accessing HTTP content through 
a proxy, potentially with authentication. For example:

>>> import nltk
>>> nltk.set_proxy('http://proxy.example.com:3128', ('USERNAME', 'PASSWORD'))
>>> nltk.download()

The username and password fields are optional to support non-authenticating 
proxies. If proxy is set to None then this function will attempt to detect the 
system proxy or raise a ValueError if a proxy can't be discovered.

At present these only handle sure alignments, but would be pretty easy to add 
in possible alignments for calculating AER.

Mostly copied directly from my own work in http://code.google.com/p/clir/.

svn/trunk@8786
Author: Dan Garrette

Message:
logic.py, drt.py

 Expression hierarchy:
 * Removed visit() from Variable since it wasn't used and didn't make sense
 * Removed 'default' parameter from visit() since it wasn't used and isn't necessary
 * visit_structured() method added.  It descends to subexpressions, applying its function to each, but then gives its parts, including the bound variables (which remain untouched), to the combinator just as they are given to the constructor.  This is useful because it is common to use the pattern of using a combinator as a constructor to created modified versions of the original object (eg replace() and normalize()), which is clumsy to implement with visit().
 * visit() no longer deals with Variables.  It descends to subexpressions but does not touch bound Variables. Thus, AbstractVariableExpressions should be treated as the terminal nodes of the visiting.  If bound Variables are needed by the combinator, visit_structured() should be used.
 * visit()'s 'combinator' now takes a list as input instead of varargs.
 * variables() has changed functionality to work with changes to the feature structure code.  Its role is now to return all variables that the binding substitution code my want to deal with.  Specifically, this means all free variables and predicates or constants that start with '?' or '@' (which have significance to feature structure code).
 * constants() method added to return all individual (non-predicate) constants.
 * predicates() method added to return all predicate constants (no variables).
 * free() now returns all free variables, individuals and predicates.
 * free() now longer has the 'indvar_only' parameter.  For the same functionality as the old "e.free(False)", use "e.free()|e.constants()".
 
 ApplicationExpression:
 * 'pred' property added (as the counterpoint to 'args') which returns the base function, the function to which all args are applied (found by uncurrying).
 * is_atom() method added for testing whether the object is an atom (and not an application of a lambda expression).
 
 
logic.doctest, drt.doctest
 * Added tests for new features, updated tests for changed features.

featgram.doctest, semantics.doctest, nonmonotonic.doctest
 * Fixed tests that were no longer working.

svn/trunk@8815
Author: Joel Nothman

Message:
Drastic efficiency improvements to weighted agreement measures

- speed-ups are of 2-3 orders of magnitude where K is large
- avoid repeatedly iterating through all items
- in particular, use FreqDists to avoid performing o(k^2.i.c) iterations


svn/trunk@8816
Author: Joel Nothman

Message:
Fix weighted-kappa bug introduced in r8816, and better logging

svn/trunk@8817
Author: Joel Nothman

Message:
Correct handling of c > 2 coders in agreement metrics

- Fix bug where pi was returning multi-pi (== Siegel and Castellan's (1998) K) with wrong normalisation constant (4 instead of c^2)
- Factor out _pairwise_average whose semantics had been rewritten differently throughout the code
- Provide multi_kappa which averages over Ao and Ae rather than over pairwise kappas

The implementations currently involve individual pairwise computations, which is not as Artstein and Poesio (2007) describe when they instead aggregate agreements for each item, ignoring coder identities. The latter is computed more efficiently. However, the current implementation illustrates more clearly the relationship between metrics for two coders and those for more.

Message:
Do not assign to the slice object

Slices are read-only, so this commit solves the following problem:

>>> s = slice(2, 10)
>>> l = list("abcdefghijlmn")
>>> nltk.slice_bounds(l, s, allow_step=True)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/peter/Projekt/NLTK/nltk/nltk/internals.py", line 781, in slice_bounds
    if slice_obj.step is None: slice_obj.step = 1
TypeError: readonly attribute
Author: Peter Ljunglöf

Message:
Removed __new__ from Tree and its subclasses

Having both __new__ and __init__ in the same class that also has subclasses can lead to problems, and easily becomes very unreadable.  I removed the __new__ method and put its functionality into __init__ instead.  I also updated the ValueError's for the Immutable classes.

Message:
Turned some ParentedTree @properties into methods

The following properties were changed to methods:
- ParentedTree: parent, parent_index, left_sibling, right_sibling, treeposition, root
- MultiParentedTree: parents, left_siblings, right_siblings, root

Note that this might break existing code that uses parented trees.

Message:
this file correspond to the generalized hamming distance
it can be used as a metric for text segmentation
it can be used the same way as the windowdiff metric, and has the same role

this implementation is a python translation of V. Kulyukin C++ code
(co-author of the paper on generalized hamming distance)
the examples in the demo function are the same that were used in
Kulyukin implementation, and allowed to compare the good behavior
of this metric to Kulyukin implementation, considered as a reference
Author: David Doukhan

cosmetics: get rid of even more CVS-style $Id$ lines

The CVS-style $Id$ lines are pretty much useless with git; and
anyway, using them would require adding proper "ident" directives
to the .gitattributes file -- and we don't have such directives.

Message:
prefer NotImplementedError over AssertionError in few places

The python documentation on "Built-in Exceptions":

  <http://docs.python.org/library/exceptions.html>

reads:

  ``In user defined base classes, abstract methods should raise
    this exception when they require derived classes to override
    the method.''

But existing NLTK code didn't consistently follow that best practice,
sometimes using 'AssertionError' or 'assert' in similar situations.
Fix that.  Also, make error messages less verbose, for consistency
with other existing code.
Author: Stefano Lattarini

Message:
Unbound methods are gone in Py3 so there is no easy way to support 'overridden' function
for unbound methods in Py3 because they look like regular functions and doesn't store reference to a class.
That feature is not used in NLTK own codebase so I removed it from tests. This make 'nltk.internals' tests
("tox -- nltk.internals internals.doctest") pass for all platforms.
Author: Mikhail Korobov

nose raises an exception under python 3 while trying to discover tests from nltk.compat.

is applied: executable bit is added to compat.py (nose skips executable files by
default). There should be a better way to do this.

Message:
wordnet reader is fixed for pypy and py3 (and its operation is restored for py26 and py27).

Wordnet tests were always failing for pypy because it is not guaranteed that strings with the same content have the same identity. After switching WordNetCorpusReader to unicode tests began to fail for python 2.6 and 2.7 because unicode string is not the same as byte string constant (even if they are equal and == returns True). This one was quite tricky to debug :)
Author: Mikhail Korobov

Author: Mikhail Korobov

Message: HunposTagger.__del__ is fixed: if the binary is not found then self._closed was undefined and thus AttributeError was raised in __del__ (and converted to a warning then).
Author: Mikhail Korobov

Author: Mikhail Korobov

Message:
numpy shouldn't be required to import nltk

'import nltk' fails without this when numpy is absent:

>>> import nltk
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "nltk/__init__.py", line 102, in <module>
    from .collocations import *
  File "nltk/collocations.py", line 39, in <module>
    from nltk.metrics import ContingencyMeasures, BigramAssocMeasures, TrigramAssocMeasures
  File "nltk/metrics/__init__.py", line 23, in <module>
    from nltk.metrics.segmentation    import windowdiff, ghd, pk
  File "nltk/metrics/segmentation.py", line 44, in <module>
    import numpy as np
ImportError: No module named numpy
Author: Mikhail Korobov

Message:
make MaltParser safe to use in a parallel setting

- Actually use self.working_dir
- Replace hard-coded temporary file names with
  tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile
- Use subprocess instead of os.system to avoid quoting issues when
  calling java
- Error out if subprocess fails
Author: Pierre-Francois Laquerre

Message:
delete temp file even if conll_file.open fails

Just moved the code inside the try block.

Message:
plug file descriptor leak in dependencygraph

This is not a major leak, since the garbage collector will destroy the
file object relatively soon, but it might still be problematic if
called in a tight loop.
Author: Pierre-Francois Laquerre

Message: clean unused variables from dependencygraph
Author: Pierre-Francois Laquerre

Message:
initialise working_dir at __init__-time

Call gettempdir() at initialisation time instead of module load time.

Message:
fix malt's mco parameter documentation

As far as I could see, MaltParser does not take a full path as input for
mco models. You must specify the name of the model, which MaltParser
then uses to look for a file in ${working_dir}/${mco}.mco. It's a bit
clunky, but I couldn't find alternatives in their documentation.
Author: Pierre-Francois Laquerre

Message:
Fixed reuse of naive bayes classifier in py3k

The NaiveBayesClassifier stored its internal label sample state as map object,
which was consumed after its first use. Converting it to a list upfront restores
the py2k behavior.

Message:
More corpus.doctest fixes: less items returned by '.words()' methods, PTB 3.x fixes, corpora path fixes.

The length of a AbstractLazySequence __repr__ becomes longer (because corpora is switched to unicode and __repr__ began to contain 'u' letters under 2.x) so it is truncated earlier than before - that's why the tests use smaller sequences.
Author: Mikhail Korobov

Message:
Substantial rewrite of the Porter Stemmer.
This was to:
1) Make it threadsafe
2) Make it more Pythonic and remove at least some of the weird C-like code from
   when it was originally ported from C
3) Remove nonsense comments referring to things like null terminated strings and
   char arrays that are meaningless in a Python context (again the result of it
   originally being ported from C)
4) Make it faster.

A test on the complete text of the King James Bible indicates that post-changes
the stemmer has entirely consistent results with the previous version and is
roughly 40% faster. It is also now threadsafe since nothing is stored in
any instance variables any more; instead things that used to be instance
variables are now passed between functions as arguments.
Author: Mark Amery

Message:
Fixed comparisons for Python 3.
- replaced `__cmp__` with `__eq__`, `__ne__` and `__lt__`, and `@total_ordering`
- added `__hash__` whenever `__eq__` is defined (new py3 semantics for `__hash__`)
- replaced `cmp` keyword argument with `key` in calls to `sort`/`sorted`
- different types should not in general be orderable, so `__lt__` raises a TypeError in these cases (exception: Tree and FeatStruct)
Author: Peter Ljunglöf

Message:
fix snowball stemmer bug in handling term `y's`

STEP 1c in line 828 checks `len(word) > 2` as last condition.
However, this will cause `string index out of range` Error
when stem the word `y's` since `word` will be `y` when we
come to line 828. Move the condition `len(word)>2` to beginning
will solve this issue.
Author: LU Chunliang

Message:
Correction of the Pk metric

The first implementation I did was 100% wrong.
According to [1] Pk should provide a penalty of about 0.5 to all degenerated segmentations (empty, full, randomized), which is not statisfied by my last implementation.
It was corrected using the explantations provided in [2]

Sorry about that

[1] Beeferman D., Berger A., Lafferty J. (1999)
Statistical Models for Text Segmentation
Machine Learning, 34, 177-210

[2] Unbiased discourse segmentation evaluation
John Niekrasz and Johanna D. Moore
Spoken Language Technology Workshop (SLT), 2010 IEEE
Page(s): 43 - 48
Author: David Doukhan

More efficient FreqDist._Nr_cache

Message:
Fixed path parsing bug

The ENV_VARS paths were not split and looped, so if a user specified
multiple directories in a single path variable, then they would be
incorrectly processed.

Fix: split the ENV_VAR on os.pathsep, loop it and then os.path.join() it
with the filename to create the possible file location.
Author: Dougal Graham

Message:
improve word_tokenize speed

Runs roughly twice as fast on my test set of 40000 sentences. According
to kernprof (http://pythonhosted.org/line_profiler/), the culprits of the
previously bad performance were

    r"([^' ])('ll|'re|'ve|n't|) "

and

    r"([^' ])('LL|'RE|'VE|N'T|) "

which were matching all words due to the | at the end.

Also removed some useless whitespace handling that was being undone by the
str.split just before return.

The contractions handling is now the slowest part @~20% of the time.
Author: Lars Buitinck

Message:
Fix bug in lemma name parsing

Lemmas containing periods were causing an exception on full name lookup: wordnet.lemma('.45_caliber.a.01..45_caliber'), wordnet.lemma('aquinas.n.01.St._Thomas'), etc. Instead of splitting on the last period, we look for two digits (the sense number) surrounded by periods.

Message:
Correction to _expected_values of ngrams

The formula for the expected values, across n_all k-grams, for n_1 n_2 ... n_k
is:

  n_all * p(n_1) * ... * p(n_k)

where p(n) is (number of occurrences of n) / n_all. The previous code's thus
had the formula wrong in two ways.

First, the denominator will be (n_all ** k), which when multiplied by n_all
gives (n_all ** (k - 1)). The previous code had (n_all ** 2), which is right
only in the case of trigrams. Since only bigrams and trigrams were created as
subclasses of NgramAssocMeasures, and the bigram object overrides this method,
the incorrect denominator probably didn't affect many people, so it was easy to
miss.

Second, for "number of occurrences of n", the code previously used the same
code that was used for bigram calculation, cont[i] + cont[i ^ j], for each j
in [1, 2, ..., 2 ** (k - 1)]. However, it's a happy accident that this works
for the bigram case.  In the trigram case, the contingency table is 2x2x2:

                    w3                       ~w3
                w1     ~w1                w1    ~w1
             ------- -------           ------- -------
         w2 | n_iii | n_oii |      w2 | n_iio | n_oio |
             ------- -------           ------- -------
        ~w2 | n_ioi | n_ooi |     ~w2 | n_ioo | n_ooo |
             ------- -------           ------- -------

The "cont[i] + cont[i ^ j]" trick takes, for each cell, the row, column, and
"pillar" (i.e. the line along the z axis) containing that cell. But only in the
bigram case is that the number of occurrences of n. Considering the first cell,
n_iii, in the trigram case, this gives (n_iii + n_oii), (n_iii + n_ioi), and
(n_iii + n_iio), which for a trigram ABC counts the occurrences of xBC, AxC,
and ABx, instead of the occurrences of Axx, xBx, and xxC. The correct number
for occurrences of w1 is the entire "left side of the cube": n_iii + n_ioi +
n_iio + n_ioo. Similarly, occurrences of w2 is the entire "back side of the
cube", and w3 is the entire "bottom of the cube" (assuming that the right
square is stacked on top of the left one).

What's actually wanted is code that says "sum the entire line/plane/hyper-plane
containing this cell, along each axis". The new code does this by finding all
cells in the same "first bit" plane, all cells in the same "second bit" plane,
etc, and summing those.

It's not a wholly intuitive formula, so I wanted to put some of this into a
comment in the method, but I wasn't able to coherently boil it down into
anything that would fit. Hopefully this commit message will be enough to,
first, convince people that the new math is correct, and second, inspire
someone to write that clarifying comment.
Author: Lance Nathan

Message:
SemcorCorpusReader was returning incomplete sense information

semcor.py was creating lemma sense tags as strings of the form `<lemma>.<sensenum>`, which is incorrect: the sense number is actually POS-specific. With this fix, SemcorCorpusReader tries to retrieve the Lemma object directly from WordNet (using the sense key). If that fails, a string of the form `<lemma>.<pos>.<sensenum>` is given.
Author: nschneid

Message:
Fixes 2.6 compatibility of numerous files

Many pieces of example code or other utility modules were trying to
import print_statement from future, which does not exist. What the
developers probably meant was print_function (in common use elsewhere in
the repository).

This branch makes it so that compileall succeeds on all .py files in the
repo.
Author: Joseph Lynch

Message: In ISRI stemmer's norm(), fix erroneous raw-string substitution
Author: Lance Nathan

Message:
ISRI stemmer: Corrections to logic (and many style fixes)

Let me stress up front: I do not speak any Arabic at all. There are a small
number of places where I have fixed some very obviously broken logic, but by
and large I have left the actual work being done by this file alone.

Places where I did change the logic:

* suf32() and pre32(). These both start with "if word is at least 6 letters
  long", and go through the length-three affixes to see if each can be
  removed. The only sensible way for the "if the word is at least 5 letters
  long, go through the length-two affixes" block to work is for it to be at
  the same indentation level, but instead (in both methods) it was indented to
  be inside the length-three affix removal block. I've reindented these.

* pro_w64(). The first check in this method was

     if (self.stm[0] and self.stm[4])=='\u0627':

  This is clearly wrong; the intent is to check whether both the first and
  fifth letters are \u0627, but instead it always fails, because a boolean is
  not equal to a string. I've changed this to be two separate conditions.

The majority of corrections in this commit are:

* pep8 changes - putting spaces around operators, standardizing the spacing of
  inline comments, etc. (I did *not* change the line lengths, though many of
  the lines are quite long, because I wasn't sure what the standard for NLTK
  is.)

* Pythonic changes - having all methods take the stem as an argument and
  return the stem, rather than modifying "self.stm" and also (sometimes, but
  not always) returning self.stm. Changing "if <condition> & <condition>" to
  "if <condition> and <condition>". That sort of thing.

* Assorted other stylistic changes - moving the hard-to-read inline comments
  on the lists in __init__ to appear above each list instead. Correcting the
  spelling of "intial" to "initial" in a variable name. Etc.
Author: Lance Nathan

Message:
Updated docs, doctests, error if text is non-ASCII

The BllipParser class docs now includes references for the parser.

The wrapper will throw an error if given non-ASCII text (at least until
we settle on a way to make it safe).

Added doctests (based on demo()), doctests are skipped if bllipparser
isn't installed.

demo() now has a stub to use nltk.download().  Since nltk_data
doesn't currently have a BLLIP model in it, I still included
bllipparser.ModelFetcher as a fallback in demo() and the doctests
so they'll still work.  We can drop this once nltk_data is updated.
Author: David McClosky

Message:
speed up path computations in WordNet reader

1296 calls to shortest_path_distance for pairs of random nouns
used to take 6.752s, now 5.364s. Subtracting 2.187s to load NLTK
and WordNet, that's 44% off.

The main speedup comes from omitting the sort in _related.
Author: Lars Buitinck

Message:
Call gs directly in nltk.tree._repr_png_, no shell

shell=True causes ghostscript to stick around with a prompt on
MacOS X

    GPL Ghostscript 9.06 (2012-08-08)
    Copyright (C) 2012 Artifex Software, Inc.  All rights reserved.
    This software comes with NO WARRANTY: see the file PUBLIC for details.
    GS>

Note that the shell=True was deliberately introduced in 0cc3d8a
to avoid a console window from popping up, possibly
related to Windows? If so, this patch may undo that change, but
maybe we can have the best of both worlds by setting the
STARTUPINFO.wShowWindow flag instead.

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3172470/actual-meaning-of-shell-true-in-subprocess
Author: Eric Kow

Message:
Fixed "About" dialog issue with Python 3.x

Attribute name "_top" was misspelled, which resulted in an error when trying to show a fallback ShowText.
tkMessageBox have been renamed to messagebox in Python 3.x. I have added another import to take this into account. From my understanding, the fallback ShowText is not needed now, but I left it just in case.
Author: Andrey Salamatin

Message:
Fixed installation with recent setuptools.

These lines were introduced here: https://github.com/nltk/nltk/commit/1ecbd2edc32db24b4e6c7dd8555d0b89c668f041
It seems they fix an issue with .svn folders. We use git now,
there are no .svn folders.

See also: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1129180/how-can-i-make-setuptools-ignore-subversion-inventory
Author: Mikhail Korobov

Message:
Fix definition of _rv_standard

The test in the definition of RV is "If the first two letters are vowels"
but this is not what `word[:2] in vowels` tests. In fact, this is False:
```python
'august'[:2] in 'aeiou'
```
Author: Helder

Merge pull request #846 from he7d3r/snowball-rv

Fix definition of _rv_standard
Author: Steven Bird

Message:
Fix step 1 replacement of 'logias' by 'log' in Portuguese Stemmer

The previous code was replacing 'logias' by 'logi'. In particular,
after this change both 'metodologias' and 'metodologia' will be
stemmed to 'metodolog'.
Author: Helder

Message:
Replace incorrect suffix 'ívelmente' by 'ivelmente'

In Portuguese, adverbs ending in 'mente' are not accented, even if they
are derived from accented adjectives. For example, these are correct:
* 'possivelmente'
* 'visivelmente'
and these are typos:
* 'possívelmente'
* 'visívelmente'

This error is also present in the description of the algorithm on
http://snowball.tartarus.org/algorithms/portuguese/stemmer.html
Author: Helder

Message:
Add 'anças' and 'ança' to the step 1 suffixes for Portuguese

These are examples of how the Portuguese Stemmer behaves after this change:

* desconfi~~ado~~ > desconfi
* __desconfi~~anças~~ > desconfi__ (was desconfianc)
* desconfi~~ar~~ > desconfi
* esper~~amos~~ > esper
* __esper~~ança~~ > esper__ (was esperanc)
* __esper~~anças~~ > esper__ (was esperanc)
* insegur~~a~~ > insegur
* __insegur~~ança~~ > insegur__ (was inseguranc)
* insegur~~o~~ > insegur
* __lider~~ança~~ > lider__ (was lideranc)
* __lider~~anças~~ > lider__ (was lideranc)
* lider~~ando~~ > lider
* __vizinh~~ança~~ > vizinh__ (was vizinhanc)
* vizinh~~os~~ > vizinh

Fixes nltk/nltk#757.
Author: Helder

Message:
Treat 'õ' and 'ã' as vowel+consonant

This way, "execução" and "execuções" will have the same stem;
Similarly for "revolução" and "revoluções".

Message:
Treat "ü" as "u" in the Portuguese stemmer

The substitution is done after "q" and "g", which are the only cases where "ü" is used
in Portuguese. This should avoid unwanted changes to proper nouns such as Kleinübing,
Kür, Müller and Schütt.

Fixes #755.
Author: Helder

Message:
Adding _repr_svg_ for Ipython notebook

The _repr_svg is implemented using dot and graphviz.
Usage in IPython notebook:

from IPython.display import display
import nltk.parse.dependencygraph as depgraph
dg = depgraph.DependencyGraph(depgraph.conll_data1)
display(dg)

Should draw the dependency graph for the sentence

Message:
framenet.py: annotation set status

Some frame annotation sets have UNANN status (no FE annotations). This change:

- Uses the annotation set offset rather than status to determine whether it contains POS tags.
- In the pretty display of a frame annotation set, displays its status.
- In the pretty display of a full-text sentence, displays the frame name for each target, and next to the annotation set offset displays "!" if its status is "UNANN".
Author: nschneid

Message:
Fix snowball scaping for "ã" and "õ"

Looks like these were needed after all (https://github.com/nltk/nltk/commit/986d10324d544df1bda41b822e8800ebf3126c1d#commitcomment-8185675)
Now "evolução" and "evoluções" are correctly stemmed to "evolu" (matching the stem of "evoluem", "evolui", "evoluir", "evoluirá", etc).
Similarly, "reconstrução" and "reconstruções" are stemmed to "reconstru" (now matching the stem for "reconstruir").

Follows up 986d10324d544df1bda41b822e8800ebf3126c1d.
Author: Helder

add date limit to rest api

streaming). Api of the method does not change. The param date_limit has

in the future, if not is a date in the past

Message:
implement add_feature_extractor function and changes related code

Specific functions that extract features from a document can now be passed as argument to the add_feature_extractor() function. These feature extractors will be later used by the extract_features() function. The advantage is in both flexibility and computational efficiency, since we are using apply_features() (and LazyMap).

Message:
automatic tests failing in Jenkins (relative paths)

automatic test failing in Jenkins since they cannot solve relative paths

One example of a test that is failing:

>Traceback (most recent call last):
>  File
"/scratch/jenkins/python/python-3.4.2-x86_64/lib/python3.4/unittest/case
.py", line 58, in testPartExecutor
>    yield
>  File
"/scratch/jenkins/python/python-3.4.2-x86_64/lib/python3.4/unittest/case
.py", line 577, in run
>    testMethod()
>  File
"/scratch/jenkins/workspace/nltk/TOXENV/py34-jenkins/jdk/jdk8latestOnlin
eInstall/nltk/test/unit/test_json2csv_corpus.py", line 61, in
test_textoutput
>    self.assertTrue(are_files_identical(outfn, ref_fn), msg=self.msg)
>  File
"/scratch/jenkins/workspace/nltk/TOXENV/py34-jenkins/jdk/jdk8latestOnlin
eInstall/nltk/test/unit/test_json2csv_corpus.py", line 29, in
are_files_identical
>    with open(filename2, "rb") as fileB:
>FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory:
'files/tweets.20150430-223406.text.csv.ref'

In order to solve `files/tweets.20150430-223406.text.csv.ref`, start
from the path of the test itself.
Author: lrnzcig

Message:
Standardize initialization and setting of training output across all IBM models

Group model parameters in __init__ so that it is easier to see what will be trained and their type.

Do not return anything from train() and update learnt parameters there instead.

Make alignment table private in Model 3, because it is not part of the training output.
Author: hoontw

Message:
Swap the order of l and m in alignment and distortion tables

This is to be consistent with GIZA++ and the original IBM model
algorithms.
Author: hoontw

Message:
Set p1 to be the learnt parameter and p0 to be derived from it

Since p0 + p1 = 1, one can be easily derived given the other. p1 is
really the parameter of interest, which is the probability that a
generated word inserts a NULL-aligned word.
Author: hoontw

Message:
Replace HashableDict with tuple

HashableDict was created to allow a collection to be added to a set. The
native tuple type can serve the same purpose.
Author: hoontw

Message:

It reads more naturally to handle the source sentence before the target
sentence.

Forbid modifications to AlignmentInfo members

Each AlignmentInfo object should have an immutable value for each of its members. This is to prevent accidental modification by any other objects holding references to the member values.

Message:
Fix incompatible type comparisons when aligning words

Cause: In the previous implementation, tuples were compared. If the
first element of both tuples were equal, the comparison would move on to
the second element. Since the second element could either be None or a
string, an exception could be thrown for comparing incompatible types.

Solution: Compare probabilities directly instead of tuples. Unbundle the
probability from the aligned position.

Fixes #986
Author: hoontw

Message: formatting fixes
Author: Steven Bird

Author: alvations

Message: Fixed typo (missing close parenthesis)
Author: alvations

Message:
Introduce extraneous training word to steal some probability mass for aligning to NULL token

In the original doctest, every target word was aligned to a non-NULL
source word. This posed a problem in imposing a probability distribution
P(target word|NULL), since this value is zero for all target words, yet
the sum of P(target word|NULL) over all target words has to be 1 in
order for it to be a proper probability distribution. As a result, some
probability values were grossly inflated so that P(target word|NULL)
will sum to 1.

To solve this, an extraneous word is introduced which legitimately
aligns to NULL. This diverts some probability mass to this word.

With real-world training data, this problem is less likely to occur, since
extraneous words are plentiful and the vocabulary sizes are larger.
Author: hoontw

Message:
Do not reset counts when a word occurs multiple times in the target sentence

When calculating normalization factors, if a word occurs more than once
in the target sentence, its count should  not be reset to zero each time
the word is encountered. The counts should be incremented from the
existing ones.

Message:
Use round instead of format in doctests to increase readability

If a large relative error would result from rounding, leave the result
as its original value, but use ellipsis after a few decimal places.

Also change a training sentence pair to the past tense, because the word
"ist" was aligning to NULL with an abnormally high score. Unfortunately,
with such a small training set, results can be brittle and shift
dramatically with a few changes in words.

Message:
Consider cost of untranslated words when translating

Distinguish between two types of scores: raw_score and (net) score. The
raw score is used for incremental calculations when expanding hypotheses
and does not include global features like the cost of untranslated
words.

Minor change to clarify parameter type in find_all_src_phrases()

Message:
Add neural dependency parser to parse.stanford

This allows the use of the new neural network dependency parser
(http://nlp.stanford.edu/software/nndep.shtml) by way of the flag
`use_nndep` to StanfordDependencyParser.

The neural version requires the full CoreNLP (tagger, etc.) jar and models
instead of the parser jars; users should ensure both are present in the
directories given by the CLASSPATH or STANFORD_MODELS environment variables.

Since using the neural dependency parser requires a different jar and increases
startup time by about 3x, this option is not enabled by default; however, the
neural dependency parser can be many times faster than the dependencies output
by the LexicalizedParser (the default implementation) if many sentences are
batched up and sent to [raw_]parse_sents.
Author: Will Monroe

Message:
Patch over tagged_parse_sents for Stanford nndep

The neural dependency parser doesn't support passing in
pre-specified tags at the command line. Fall back to ignoring
them rather than crash or spit out bogus trees.
Author: Will Monroe

Message:
Fix skipped token handling in CONLL dependencies

Longer CONLL outputs (7-cell/10-cell) include indices that can
be non-contiguous. This results in parts of the tree being
disconnected and silently dropped in the output of methods like
DependencyGraph.tree(). Now these trees will be correctly
connected.
Author: Will Monroe

Message: Add doctests for Stanford neural dependency parser
Author: Will Monroe

Message: Add myself to authors file
Author: Will Monroe

Message:
Split neural dependency parser into its own class

This gets rid of several messy if statements and allows the
doctests to be integrated with the code, in addition to the
benefit of consistency with the organization of other external
parser classes.
Author: Will Monroe

Message:
Fixed issue  #1203

In python 3, instead of a list some methods (e.g. filter/reduce) return iterators instead of a sequence (c.f. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1303347/getting-a-map-to-return-a-list-in-python-3-x) this was fixed by surrounding these calls with list(...). Additionally I implemented lazy corpus loading.

Message:
Update the default download URL to use https://

The index file that the downloader uses is currently served from GitHub
Pages (via http://www.nltk.org), but while GitHub Pages doesn't directly
offer https://, they provide an alternate way to easily download files
securely over https:// via their `raw.githubusercontent.com` FQDN.

This helps protect the index and the file URLs listed in it from being
MITM'd and modified to something malicious and just helps with ensuring
file integrity.
Author: Reed Loden

Message:
Fix a bug on sentiwordnet

In the current implementation, sentiment synsets of some adjectives
are not found, due to the fact that in SentiWordNet corpus
there exist no 's' tag, which stands for 'adjective satellite.'
This modifies the code to treat 's' tag as 'a', so that it can find
synsets of adjectives correctly.
To see the change, check synsets of the word 'crazy.'
Author: Jihun Choi

Author: Michael Wayne Goodman

Message:
Fix dict-order issue with probability.doctest

The FreqDist class is a subclass of Counter, and while Counter sorts elements by count, "elements with equal counts are ordered arbitrarily" (https://docs.python.org/3/library/collections.html#collections.Counter.most_common).

This arbitrary ordering causes issues with doctests, because doctests require strict string equivalence, and the ordering can vary across Python versions and platforms (i.e., the test may pass for one version of Python on a certain platform, but it is not guaranteed to do so elsewhere).

I decided to fix the doctest by changing the distributions so that no two elements had an equal count for any of the operations. There are other ways to fix the test (e.g., manually sorting the FreqDist by count and then by element, or by comparing the result with expected values and looking for True values), this change still follows the spirit of the original doctest in showcasing the behavior of the class.
Author: Michael Wayne Goodman

Message:
Fix implementation error on Method3 Smoothing

The smooth should only affect the precision count not the ngram precision itself, so the `p_i.denominator` needs to be considered, i.e.`(1/2**k) / p_i.denominator`. Simplified mathematically to `1/ (2**k * p_i.denominator)`

Message:
Fixes doctest for python3

Dictionary hash are dynamic in Python3 so the __repr__ output will be different all the time. Doctest should check for value equality instead. 

Fixes issue on https://nltk.ci.cloudbees.com/job/nltk/TOXENV=py34-jenkins,jdk=jdk8latestOnlineInstall/lastCompletedBuild/testReport/nltk.tokenize.mwe/MWETokenizer/add_mwe/
Author: alvations

Message:
Fixes doctest for python3

Dictionary hash are dynamic in Python3 so the __repr__ output will be different all the time. Doctest should check for value equality instead. Monotonic nested defaultdict/dictionary outputs should not be affected though.

Fixes issue on https://nltk.ci.cloudbees.com/job/nltk/TOXENV=py34-jenkins,jdk=jdk8latestOnlineInstall/lastCompletedBuild/testReport/nltk.util/Trie/as_dict/

(Same issue as https://github.com/nltk/nltk/commit/a488bb6c900c89ea4d2ca154627fa92093626332)

@stevenbird Sorry I presented the wrong radio button in the previous commit when fixing https://github.com/nltk/nltk/commit/a488bb6c900c89ea4d2ca154627fa92093626332

Message:
fix up AlignedSent._repr_svg_() for Python 3. Python 2 compatible.

Plotting is done using the example from the class docstring. Open up IPython notebook and paste:

>>> from nltk.translate import AlignedSent, Alignment
>>> algnsent = AlignedSent(['klein', 'ist', 'das', 'Haus'],
>>> ['the', 'house', 'is', 'small'], Alignment.fromstring('0-2 1-3 2-1 3-0'))
>>> algnsent

This commit fixes the following bug when using Python 3, which represents subprocess output
as bytes instead of str, to draw an AlignedSent in IPython:

/usr/lib/python3.5/site-packages/IPython/core/formatters.py:367: FormatterWarning: image/svg+xml formatter returned invalid type <class 'bytes'> (expected (<class 'str'>,)) for object: AlignedSent(['klein', 'ist', 'das', 'Haus'], ['the', 'house', 'is', 'small'], Alignment([(0, 2), (1, 3), (2, 1), (3, 0)]))
  FormatterWarning
Author: David Madl

This uses lazy loading by default in `words()`, `tagged_words()`, `sents()`, `tagged_sents()`, `participants()`, `age()`, and `MLU()`. Respects the setting in `self._lazy`.

Not sure if this is the most elegant solution, but it seems to work.
Author: nschneid

Message:
Stabilize BLEU to handle fringe cases

 - When initializing the Fraction object calculated by the `modified_precision()`, we set the denominator to 1 to handle ZeroDivisionError. This is consistent with the fact that when the reference is empty, any hypothesis to it would be superfluous hence they should be penalize to 0. 

-  Additional condition to handle empty hypothesis. When hypothesis length is 0, there should be no score regardless of whether the reference is empty. By setting the brevity penalty to 0, we immediately cause the BLEU -> 0 since `BLEU = bp * smoothen(precisions)`.
Author: alvations

Message:
Deal gracefully with degenerate cases.

This edit deals with a degenerate case in Krippendorff's alpha - if there is only one class.

current behaviour throws a ZeroDivisionError, this edit changes that to return complete agreement (since there is only one class)

How should we deal with no data (ie: len(self.K)==0)? Currently it'll raise a zero division error also, which isn't too informative...

Message:
Rewrite porter.py

- Added three modes: one faithful to the original paper, one to M Porter's extended version, and one to NLTK's extended version.

  This point resolves https://github.com/nltk/nltk/issues/139
- As a consequence, ensured all NLTK-specific departures were clearly marked (wasn't previously true)
- Added unit tests. These use Martin Porter's recommended testing vocabulary from http://tartarus.org/martin/PorterStemmer/voc.txt. Expected output for the Martin-extended version of the stemmer is likewise taken from his site; expected output for the original and NLTK versions was generated by running, respectively, the C version of the stemmer written by Martin and the NLTK version of the stemmer prior to this commit against the testing vocabulary.
- Fixed the demo
- Made code at least roughly comply with PEP 8
- Purged copyright notice wrongly attributing authorship
- Moved comments about contributors into the contributors file, where they better belong
- Made function names more verbose and algorithm details more simple with the aim of improving readability
- Documented steps in the algorithm with quotes from the original paper by Martin Porter, currently hosted at http://tartarus.org/martin/PorterStemmer/def.txt
- Removed a load of commented-out code that I guess had originally been taken from whatever source porter.py was originally copied into NLTK from

Minor compatability-breaking changes, with justification:

- Removed call to _adjust_case prior to stemming; this isn't part of the Porter algorithm, and isn't done by other NLTK stemmers like Lancaster or Snowball, so it seemed wrong
- Remove stem_word from PorterStemmer. It does pretty much the same as stem(), and isn't part of the StemmerI interface. Anybody who was previously using it (hopefully nobody) can just change their code to call stem() if they update NLTK.
Author: Mark Amery

Message:
Fixes several errors in remove_handles

I updated the regular expression from remove_handles so that it now achieves the following:
 - Handles can begin with numbers
 - Handles are allowed to follow any of the following characters: `~()-=+\|[]{};:'\"/?.,<> \n
 - Handles are allowed to precede the following characters: !#$%&*
 - Handles have a max length of 20 (15 today, but it was 20 in the past so the max length handle you can tweet is 20)
 - Two @ in a string with only alphanumeric characters and _ between them are not handles
 - Unless the first handle is 20 characters long and there is at least one more character before the next @

The above changes may seem oddly specific, and that's because they are. These changes were not found through any Twitter documentation, but rather tweeting various test cases and observing which were tagged as handles by Twitter.

The following is a link to a gist that tests the previous regex against my suggested change:
(HINT: mine passes all the tests and the previous regex fails nearly all of them)
https://gist.github.com/hdlim15/2419dd8f6bb3987f4a3536a4008b0544
Author: hdlim15

Message:
Small improvement for consistency

Replace handles with a space (i.e. " ") instead of the empty string (i.e. "") to ensure that text on either side of removed handles are tokenized correctly
Author: hdlim15

Message:
Added test cases for remove_handle

Test cases for the following change:
https://github.com/nltk/nltk/pull/1521

Writing the expected results was a little difficult as the behavior around adjacent punctuation and especially "@"s that are not part of Twitter handles is confusing. I am pretty sure the test cases are correct, but if one of them fails when it shouldn't I would be happy to take another look.
Author: hdlim15

Message:
strip trailing whitespace in sentence splitting (#1534)

In sentence splitting, the last sentence should not have trailing whitespace.
This is consistent with how the non-last sentences are treated, and also
how the last sentence is treated by _realign_boundaries(), in case it ends
with a parenthesis.

Message:
Continued overhaul of FrameNet corpus reader so it loads and pretty-prints annotated sentences.

## Major API changes

- `fes()` now accepts an optional `frame` parameter, which can be a pattern string, a frame ID, or a frame instance
- `lus()` likewise accepts a `frame` parameter
- `exemplars()` likewise accepts a `frame` parameter, as well as 1-2 FE parameters to filter results to sentences where those FEs are overtly realized

## Minor improvements and fixes

- `LazyIteratorList` moved to nltk.util
- Provide access to special layers (besides Target and FE layers): NER, WSL, Sent, Other, Noun, Verb, Adj, etc.
  * The POS-specific layers (Noun, Verb, Adj, ...) are displayed in the pretty-print display of the annotation set 
(usually in the same line as the first FE layer, but sometimes a separate line is required)
- Flag `Problem` status LUs with `?` in the full-text sentence display
- The full-text sentence display now has a mechanism for displaying multiple annotation sets of the same frame per target, as well as a less beautiful fallback display for identical/overlapping target spans with different frames
- Minor data cleanliness issues now reported via warnings, which are off by default
- Fix infinite recursion in `frame_by_name()` by checking for identity-containment rather than equals-containment
- Placeholder mechanism when an annotation set for an undefined LU is encountered
- Load `cBy`, `cDate`, and `mDate` metadata attributes
- As well as each frame's, LU's, and FE's plain-text `definition`, also store `definitionMarkup`, which flags FEs in the definition text
- For numerals, ensure lexeme name is a string
- Sort lexemes by their specified ordering rather than XML order
- For full-text sentences, store target spans/LU name/frame name in `.targets`
Author: Nathan Schneider

Message:
Allow iterator in perceptron tagger training

We'd like to allow ``sentences`` to be either a list or an iterator,
the latter being especially important for a large training dataset.
We first initialize an empty list of ``self._sentences``.
Because ``self._make_tagdict(sentences)`` runs regardless, we make
it populate ``self._sentences`` with all the sentences.
This saves the overheard of just iterating through ``sentences`` to
get the list by ``sentences = list(sentences)``.
Author: jacksonllee

Message:
Fix a bug on Python 3.3 and earlier versions

The `reload` function in python version 3.0 to 3.3 is located in the `imp` module and after 3.4 the `imp` module gets depracated and the `reload` function moved to `importlib` module

You can see:

https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.0.html?highlight=reload#builtins

https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.4.html?highlight=reload#importlib
Author: Abdelhak Bougouffa

Message:
Addresses #1667; add gleu_score.corpus_gleu()

From an email thread on nltk-dev, we got some more information about
the corpus-level GLEU calculation. I used that to create a
corpus_gleu() function in nltk.translate.gleu_score. I did not change
the functions to accept multiple references per hypothesis because
that would change the API, and it doesn't appear that the authors of
GLEU implemented it (though they suggested it could just be the max
score among the references). If we want to allow it, we could do
something like:

 1. Inspect if the reference argument is `list(str)` or
    `list(list(str))` automatically, and silently adapt to the input.
 2. Allow an optional `multiple_reference` parameter which, when True,
    expects the reference argument to be multiple references.
 3. Wait for the next major version of NLTK and change the API.
Author: Michael Wayne Goodman

Message:
.gitignore some non-ignored stuff that running `tox` creates

Previously, after I ran tox I saw all this untracked stuff in my repo:

```
mark@lunchbox:~/nltk$ git status
On branch develop
Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)

	brown.embedding
	model.crf.tagger
	pylintoutput
```

I'm guessing it should all be ignored.
Author: Mark Amery

The new version of stanford-segmenter-2016-10-31 don't need the path of slf4j

Now the stanford_segmenter.py is not working using the new release of
stanford-segmenter-2016-10-31.

Since the exception is threw when executing the java cmd, I tested the
following cmd and finally catch the bug.

1. work (the existing version of segment.sh from
stanford-segmenter-2016-10-31)

  java -mx2g -cp ./*: edu.stanford.nlp.ie.crf.CRFClassifier
-sighanCorporaDict ./data -textFile input.txt -inputEncoding UTF-8
-sighanPostProcessing true -keepAllWhitespaces false -loadClassifier
./data/ctb.gz -serDictionary ./data/dict-chris6.ser.gz

Message:
changes according to dimazest's advice

I have read the code of find_jar_iter in the internals.py.
If path_to_slf4j is set to 'slf4j-api.jar' and input to find_jar()
directly, the searching process will execute:

    if path_to_jar is not None:
        if os.path.isfile(path_to_jar):
            yielded = True
            yield path_to_jar
        else:
            raise LookupError('Could not find %s jar file at %s' %
                            (name_pattern, path_to_jar))

and ignore the environment variables.  So in the default situation we
need to set path_to_jar to None.
Author: Zing

Message:
Add environment variable option for DL_URL

With GH-1787 we have come to realize that we need a method to locally
cache NLTK data so that we are not affected by outages caused by
upstream infrastructure. The proposal here is to allow an environment
variable NLTK_DOWNLOAD_URL to be set which will allow us to configure an
override on CI systems to force all of our projects that call
ntlk.downloader to download from a local copy of nltk data instead of
from upstream default URL.

Issue: GH-1787
Signed-off-by: Thanh Ha <thanh.ha@linuxfoundation.org>
Author: Thanh Ha

Message:
Avoid mention of source and target language in AlignedSent

This keeps AlignedSent general. Also, IBM models use mots as the source
and words as the target, contradicting the documentation of AlignedSent.

Additionally, fix wrong alignment used in the __init__ doctest so that
the order of alignment is (words_index, mots_index)

Credit to DavidNemeskey for identifying this long-standing discrepancy.

Fixes #1888
Author: hoontw

Message:
Change word alignment format in examples to be consistent with rest of NLTK

* Use zero-based numbering
* Express each alignment in the order (words_index, mots_index)

Message:
Split CoNLL lines at single tabs

CoNLL should be separated by a single tab.
Some CoNLL files (like the Hamburg Dependency Treebank) are treating words like "New York" as a single form with a space!
The CoNLLReader couldn't read those files.

References:
HDT: https://corpora.uni-hamburg.de/hzsk/de/islandora/object/treebank:hdt
Author: Björn Ebbinghaus

Message:
Remove special handling of slices in getitem methods

Prior to  pep-357, special handling of slices was required as only 
integers and long integers were accepted for slicing.

After pep-357, special handling of slices is not required and should be
removed to improve code quality.

Message:
Fix UnboundLocalError bug and add tests for TextTilingTokenizer

In TextTilingTokenizer, when illegal arguments are passed for `similarity_method` or
`smoothing_method`, an `UnboundLocalError` exception is thrown.  This is caused by
local variables being set in an `if` statement with no `else` branch.  This fix adds
an `else` branch that raises an exception if an illegal argument is used.

Additionally, doctests have been added for TextTilingTokenizer.
Author: Brandon M. Burroughs

Message:
Fix ConditionalFreqDist mutation on tabulate/plot call

Since self[c] adds c to the ConditionalFreqDist regardless of
whether c is a valid condition or not, calling tabulate or plot
with condtiions not in the cfd puts them in conditions, causing
errors when it's called again. Checking to see whether c is in
self before calling self[c] prevents this problem.
Author: Iris Zhou

Message:
Patch Tree classes to work with native Python copy library

Link __copy__ and __deepcopy__ to copy function defined in Tree
classes. This allows the native Python copy library to work with
Tree, ImmutableTree, and ParentedTree.

Message:
Update decisiontree.py

    See issue #1524.

    For classifier features having a boolean value or being of NoneType and being mixed with features of type String,
    sorted() does not work in Python3 (but it did in Python2).
    This resulted in an error message and no output
    when trying to pretty_print() the decision tree or printing it in pseudocode().

    I added a sort key function, which creates a tuple for each item (feature value) to be sorted:

    First item in the tuple is a truth value (True if item is None/True/False, otherwise False),
    second item the item cast to a lowercase string.

    This results in a sorting order where
    - all items of non-None/True/False-type come first (first element of tuple is True and True < False)
    and will be sorted by their lowercase string version
    - then, items of type None/True/False will follow (in the order of their lowercase string version, so: False, None, True)

    This change will allow users working with feature values None/True/False in Python3,
    being able to use pretty_print() and pseudocode().

    Output feature values will still be sorted,
    values None/True/False added at the and of the sorted list.
Author: Gerhard Kremer

Message:
Provide  actionable error message in RegexpTagger

The RegexpTagger error messages are obscure when a regexp has an error.
This is because re messages may be obscure too.

To help with tracing the cause or regex errors, we now catch regex
compilation errors when a RegexpTagger is contrsuctor and raise a new
exception that contains the required diagnostic information with the
error message, the faulty regex and its corresponding tag.

The RegexpTagger.decode_json_obj has been streamlined also to avoid code
duplication and use the default constructor instead.

Signed-off-by: Philippe Ombredanne <pombredanne@nexb.com>
Author: Philippe Ombredanne

Message:
Fix JSON encoding and decoding of NgramTaggers

Remove encode_json_obj() and decode_json_obj() from subclasses of NgramTagger. Provide serialization support to ngrams of size greater than 1: every key in _context_to_tag is converted to its repr string and loaded using ast.literal_eval. If _context_to_tag is empty, it means that all contexts were excluded since the backoff tagger covers them and the backoff tagger can be used instead.
Author: alexandredias3d

Message:
FreqDist ordering based on partial order

Change the implementation of <= and >= for FreqDist
so they are both a partial order.

With the old implementation for a pair of two frequency
distributions each could be bigger than the other.

>>> a = FreqDist('aab')
>>> b = FreqDist('abb')
>>> a > b
True
>>> b > a
True

This is very unintuitive as it ignores both common sense
and the mathematical definition of order.

It should be noted that the new ordering scheme is a not
a total order and that both a <= b and b <= a are False.
Author: Pyfisch

Message:
Remove obsolete code

Remove obsolete c-version imports of Python modules as Python 3 automatically choses the fastest implementation.
Replace BufferedGzipFile with compatibility placeholder and deprecate it.

Remove no longer used six from pip-req.txt
Remove singledispatch dependency which was not needed since Python 3.4

Closes #2505

Message:
Include licensing files in built wheel explicitly

LICENSE.txt is included automatically in a built wheel, but that is not
enough. This commit makes the inclusion of LICENSE.txt explicit rather
than implicit and adds the AUTHORS.md and README.md that contain
additional licensing and credit information that were otherwise missing
from a built wheel.

Signed-off-by: Philippe Ombredanne <pombredanne@nexb.com>
Author: Philippe Ombredanne

Message:
Skip inconsistent test (#2605)

* Skip inconsistent test

There is a ~1.8% chance that this test will randomly fail, despite working correctly.

* Reduced precision of tagger evaluation test

Rather than skipping, reducing the precision to between 70% and 80%, rather than between 73% and 74% seems like the best solution for preserving the test, while keeping the test easily readable.
Author: Tom Aarsen

Message: Fixes Issue #2420 (WordNet sense keys mismatch) (#2621)
Author: Eric Kafe

Message:
Fix bug in meteor (#2619)

* passing preprocess arg to single_meteor_score function call

* adding test case

* updating authors
Author: Akshita Bhagia

Message: Added a validity check of the synset offset parameter in synset_from_pos_and_offset() (#2625)
Author: Eric Kafe

Message:
LazyIteratorList in nltk.collections throws StopIteration exception when getting list length (#2617)

* Remove unnecessary increment

* Prevent looping until StopIteration

When StopIteration is encountered, simply return. This prevents calling `len()` on a LazyIteratorList to throw a StopIteration exception.

* Replace unused for loop variables with _

* Fixed typo in assertion

* Added doctest for changes

* Removed unnecessary exception variable
Author: Tom Aarsen

Message:
POS tagger throws IndexError when passed empty string (#2620)

* Prevent crash on tagging empty string

Empty string seems to evaluate to "NN" with a conf of around 0.99. This seems preferable to an IndexError.

* Simplified if-return-elif tree

* Revert "Simplified if-return-elif tree"

This reverts commit 6fff71938b7ef1fc345af98972f5629facfaf6e4.

* Revert "Prevent crash on tagging empty string"

This reverts commit 4d5baf1ed0f399798a9a66174a426db183b4bc05.

* Prevent crash on tagging empty string

Empty string seems to evaluate to "NN" with a conf of around 0.99. This seems preferable to an IndexError.

* Simplified if-return-elif tree

* Fixed typo in comment

* Added test: ensure tagging an empty string doesn't throw an exception
Author: Tom Aarsen

Message:
Run tests in pytest, not nose (#2595)

* Run nltk tests in pytest, not nose

* Explain alternatives to --doctest-continue-on-failure

* fixed weird whitespace in authors

* Responded to comments, removed runtests.py, updated documentation

* grammar is hard

Co-authored-by: Steven Bird <stevenbird1@gmail.com>
Author: Danny Sepler

Message:
Fixes issue #2314 (Infinite loop in Wordnet closure and tree) (#2612)

* Fixes issue #2314 (Infinite loop in Wordnet closure and tree)

* Edited comments for closure and tree

* use pop(0) instead of pop() to output closure in correct order

* Include the caller node in acyclic_breadth_first() output, but discard it in Wordnet closure(). Improved comment in acyclic_depth_first().

* use deque instead of list

* Warn directly about each cycle instead of collecting them in a list

* Use acyclic_branch_depth_first for wordnet.tree, handle harder cycles with acyclic_depth_first

* fixed typo, added doctests

* doctests: adapted calls to match the documented function
Author: Eric Kafe

Message:
Fix treebank detokenizer (#2575)

* Add tests for TreebankWordDetokenizer

Currently, the detokenizer doesn’t hanlde quotes quite well.

Signed-off-by: Or Sharir <or@sharir.org>

* Fix quotes substitution

Python’s double-quote raw strings cannot represent a single double-quote. Use single-quote raw strings instead (though a regular string would suffice too).

Signed-off-by: Or Sharir <or@sharir.org>

* Fixed issues with start and end quotes

* `` and '' should always be replaced with double quotes, regardless of spaces.
* Starting quotes should remove padding just on the right.
* Ending quotes should remove padding just on the left.
* The way tokenizer works, you first convert starting/ending quotes to their respective symbol and then add padding as needed. The detokenizer should work the same way and replace the spceial token back to double quotes only at the last regex.

Signed-off-by: Or Sharir <or@sharir.org>

* Fix padding around commas and colons

The tokenizer checks for non-digits because we don’t want to add padding inside numbers and time formats (e.g., “1,000” or “9:30”). However, the detokenizer’s input will never have a colon/comma with spaces around if it was part of a number/time string. Thus, at this last point we just need to remove left padding in all cases, instead of checking for non-digit or whitespace (to handle cases where there’s a comma followed by double-quotes).

Signed-off-by: Or Sharir <or@sharir.org>

* Add my name to author’s list

Signed-off-by: Or Sharir <or@sharir.org>

* Added more tests for some edge cases.

Signed-off-by: Or Sharir <or@sharir.org>

* Fix case of quotes followed by punctuation

Signed-off-by: Or Sharir <or@sharir.org>

* Fix edges cases at end/start of a line

We shouldn’t catch whitespace in most cases where we don’t remove it because it prevents matching at end/start of a line, e.g., when a line ends on a right parentheses we should still remove the left padding.

Signed-off-by: Or Sharir <or@sharir.org>

* Comment out unneeded lines

(I keep them in code as a reminder for the reversed order in the tokenizer)

Signed-off-by: Or Sharir <or@sharir.org>

* Remove redundent + sign. Corrent comment.

Signed-off-by: Or Sharir <or@sharir.org>

* Add test for parentheses at end/start of line.

Signed-off-by: Or Sharir <or@sharir.org>

Co-authored-by: Steven Bird <stevenbird1@gmail.com>
Author: Or Sharir

Message:
setup.py: fix python_requires (#2720)

Fix python_requires to specify a valid version.  Apparently, combining
>= and .* is disallowed, and I'm pretty sure 'just' >=3.5 means
the same.

To reproduce the problem, you can:

    $ pip install nltk distlib
    $ python -c "import distlib.database; \
      distlib.database.DistributionPath().get_distribution('nltk')"

which yields a (not very readable) error of:

    ValueError: '.*' not allowed for '>=' constraints
Author: Michał Górny
Tom Aarsen

Message:
Prevent `debug_decisions` in Punkt from throwing IndexError (#2769)

* Preventing `debug_decisions` in Punkt from throwing an exception

Previously, an IndexError was thrown whenever the passed sentence contained a sentence ending in "!", "?" or a character in a custom `sent_end_chars`.

* Added `debug_decisions` tests - modified test loading

- Three new tests were added for punkt tokenize, and debug_decisions. All three of these tests failed previously.
- Also, previously the entire test file is skipped when the Stanford tokenizer and segmenting jars are missing. After this, only the Stanford tests are skipped

* Added a debug_decisions test with no splitting

* Ensure that the while loop cannot throw an IndexError

* Renamed `stanford_segmenter` to `check_stanford_segmenter`

Also trimmed whitespace

* Parametrized tests and fixed typos

* Removed unneeded comma

* Blacked test_tokenize.py
Author: Tom Aarsen

Message:
Visualize WordNet relation graphs using Graphviz (#2740)

* v. 3.6

* Add Wordnet graph visualisations

* Add dot2img, with more output formats

* Discard cycles in edge_closure()

* Restore less restrictive file permissions

* Add options for orientation and maxdepth

* Change orientation to 'up' or 'down'

* Default orientation is 'down' (draw source nodes at the bottom)

* Add 'verbose' option to warn about cycles

* Add 'boxes' parameter for box-shaped nodes

* Improve docstrings

* Draw eventual bidirectional edges

* General digraph function for mixed inputs

* Change orientation parameter; add doctests

* Orientation is 'default' or 'reverse'

* edge_closure returns a set

* Add doctest

* edge_closure() yields edges in BFS order

* Add shapes and global graph attributes

* Apply code suggestions by @tomaarsen

* Draw Minimum Spanning Tree as directed graph

* Renamed 'x'es

Co-authored-by: Steven Bird <stevenbird1@gmail.com>
Author: Eric Kafe

Message:
Modernised nltk.org website (#2845)

* Added favicon, icon, moved to nltk_theme theme

Also made some small renaming changes and fixed in the .rst files.

* Significant changes to Documentation building

* Now use `better_apidoc` instead of `sphinxcontrib.apidoc`.
* This better apidoc allows for templating. I've added very simple templates for these.
* NLTK News -> Release Notes
* Split up the Table of Contents on the left hand side for more visual clarity.
* Edited some settings, e.g. autodoc_typehints

* Updated footer and TOC

* Add Module Index to TOC tree

* Remove logo, use text there instead

* Separated Team from Contribution

* Improved backticks on install documentation

* Remove nltk.rst

This file shouldn't be pushed to GitHub

* Move to using pip installed nltk_theme

* Set build-dir to 'build'

* Update RELEASE-HOWTO

* Move to using sphinx-build

* Small cleanup

* Clarified importance of creating a new tag
Author: Tom Aarsen

Message:
Fixed several TreebankWordTokenizer and NLTKWordTokenizer bugs (#2877)

* Fixed issue with quote-tokenization, small regression for detokenization

* Updated double-quote to single quote in doctest output

* Resolved issue with 'wanna' absorbing a space too much in (de)tokenization

* Allow importing TreebankWordDetokenizer from nltk.tokenize

* Added additional test for span_tokenize

* Add span_tokenize to NLTKWordTokenizer, like in TreebankWordTokenizer

* Added credits for modifications
Author: Tom Aarsen

Message:
Partition `tree.py` module into `tree` package + pickle fix (#2863)

* Resolved un-pickling issue with ParentedTrees for Python 3.7+

* Split tree.py up into its own module

* Fixed improper import from tree/probabilistic.py

* Import tree in the list of packages, instead of modules

* The label for a node doesn't need to be a str, it can be Any

* Renamed
ltk.tree.parse to
ltk.tree.parsing to avoid accidental overwrites

* Moved TreePrettyPrinter to tree package

The old import still works, but throws a warning. Perfect!

* Improved import issue with prettyprinter

* Moved treetransforms functions to tree package

* Heavily shrunk treetransforms.py

* Prevent shallow copy on ParentedTree - added doctest w. documentation

* Deprecate GhostScript in favor of svling

See #2875
Author: Tom Aarsen

Message:
Use regex instead of re to combat exponential backtracking

caused by a Large Starting Qualifier. This is not a ReDoS as this has no attack vector - the compilation is only slow if the compilation fails, and if a compilation is allowed to fail, then there are likely other issues to take care of.

Message:
Remove space before context word in _match_potential_end_contexts

The space was always just filtered away by '_tokenize_words', so it does not affect the tokenizer. However, it should improve the output of debug_decisions, as there's now no longer the useless space in the 'text' field. Beyond that, it better matches the original vision of the method.
Author: Tom Aarsen

Message:
Close tempfile before attempting to remove it

I'm not a big fan of writing to files without the 'with open(...) as f' context manager notation, but this will do just fine.

Message:
Skip setting up Senna instances in doctests

These can throw LookupError's if the SENNA env variable is defined, like in the CI. Long story short, it's easiest to skip these, and we won't miss out on test coverage, as Senna should already be tested in test/unit/test_senna.py by the Linux workers
